description:
While walking around Chinatown, my party of two decided to try this shop for tea tasting. Although you could seat up to 6 people for a $35 session, we decided to try it with our small party anyways. First, we had to choose 4 teas out of the 8 options available. Then, a kind lady sat us down and guided us through the teas. 

A few things I would like to note about that place is that I loved how clean and tidy the place was! The cleanliness of the place definitely made the experience great. Also, the lady who served us was very kind and answered any of our questions. Last, I personally loooved the Formosa Red #18 tea and would definitely recommend trying that one! It has such a natural sweet flavor despite not having any sweetener added, and it smells delicious!
author: Julia S.

description:
Tea shop with tastings. The way it works is that they offer tastings of 3 teas for $30 per group of people. A salesperson sits with you through the tasting to explain and prepare the teas, and tries to sell you teas and glassware, etc.

My first disappointment was that they did not put any effort into helping us select which teas to taste. In hindsight we really should have browsed the store and picked some out before talking to a salesperson.

The actual teas we tried were pretty good, as was the preparation. The salesperson rambled through a script full of half-truths and posudoscience about the benefits of tea as we went, which I found somewhat annoying. Once the core tasting was complete we were left alone to enjoy the extra tea, which was greatly appreciated.

I did end up buying some leaves, but in general the prices seemed quite high and the experience was not good enough to make me inclined to buy more.
author: Christian P.

description:
Delicious tea.

The offer high quality teas and reasonable prices. Employees are hard working, incredibly helpful and knowledgeable. They are so patient too, taking their time to explain their teas. They sell a variety of teas, teaware, gift sets, etc. This is a great place to find a gift for that tea lover in your life. The tea shop was clean and organized. Their teas are clean, flavorful, and have a smooth finish. 

Glad we got a chance to visit!
author: Kimberly J.

description: I came in for the full tea experience, & I got it here. Perfect for a rainy day.  They offer tea flights, that include your choice of 3 out of the shown menu. You should probably reserve ahead of time, but I got lucky mid day during the week.  I received a private lesson in tea.  They are very knowledgeable, & walk you through every step of the process.  I was very impressed.
author: Joby W.

description: Feliz was amazing, we literally came in off the street looking for loose leaf teas when we came across this gem.  I thought I knew a great deal about tea, but I was sadly mistaken.  The demonstration and sampling was a great experience for my daughter, as well, since she loves teas as well.  Cannot recommend enough.  Feliz was knowledgeable, friendly, and gave us some great tips for cold brewing.  Like I stated, she was just amazing.
author: Ryan R.

description: I went here with Debra R and Jose R. We bought a bag of oolong tea and another bag of jasmine tea. The customer service was good.
author: Julia R.

description: Love! This shop is very crisp and clean. Everything is clearly labeled, so you know exactly what you're getting. I couldn't chose which to buy so I needed up getting a box sampler set. You really can't go wrong in this place because all the teas are great quality. The staff is super knowledgeable and help guide you to the tea you might want to buy.
author: Ellie G.

description:
We really love tea and wanted to get some new ones... My husband bookmarked this place a while ago and last time we were in Chinatown, we decided to try it. The place is very lovely and the teas smell amazing.

We chose to have a tasting and tried three different teas (dragonwell and two different kind of jasmine tea). The person who took care of us was really nice and he explained a lot about the teas we were tasting. It was very interesting and useful too.

We bought two of the two teas we tried (dragonwell and a jasmine tea in little pearls) and also got little cups to drink tea. We really appreciate the advice they gave us and we will come back! Thanks for the experience!
author: Caroline P.

description: Definitely a fan of this place. The staff takes their time with you and explains things. Additionally, free sample of something you are interested in buying. The tea itself is great quality and we have not been disappointed after coming here many times over the years. When I come back in town to SF, this is one of my top spots to check out and get some tea for home. Good quality, friendly staff, reasonable price.
author: Amanda P.

description:
Bottom Line:  Quality tea and trustworthy service in a clean store that is transparent about their practices and packages.

If you want good quality tea and want to purchase it from a knowledgeable and trustworthy source then come to Red Blossom.  Having tried tea up and down Grant Ave. in Chinatown I think Red Blossom is the best, by far.  Although the store may look new and modern, they have actually been in business for over 30 years.  This family owned store is serious about sourcing pure and quality tea and I think their clean and minimalist displays echo that sentiment.  

Alice, who I presume is the owner, grew up in the tea business as her father was the entrepreneur of this great shop.  Alice is very knowledgeable about tea - not just from reading about it, tasting it and growing up in the business but also from traveling to China to visit tea plantations.  She visits tea plantations once or twice a year to see the process followed by farmers and to make sure they are not directly using pesticides or getting overspray of pesticides from neighboring farms.  Given Red Blossom's attention to detail it is not surprising that their tea is featured in many Michelin-Star restaurants throughout the United States.  The many varieties of teas sold at Red Blossom are perfect as is - there is no need to doctor them with milk of sweeteners. 

Alice is not just an expert in Chinese tea, she is an expert in the tastes and customs of tea served around the world.  I really appreciate that her context for tea extends beyond that of China and that her personal ties to England have given her another perspective.
author: Courtney K.

description: The moment I walked in this store I was shocked by how nice it was. I loved how they had tea lining up along the shelves and how in the front you could try the tea they had there. The tea was very good. I first walked in that store last summer and I keep ordering tea from there. I recently ordered 4 oz of the honey orchid oolong tea for about 60$ and I would highly recommend it. Another great one is the golden monkey first pick black tea and that was the first tea I bought I would also highly recommend ( about 17$ for 2oz ). They also have very nice tea sets. When I was there I bought a 20$ tea set and I use it frequently. The costumer Service was amazing they were very friendly and helpful. I was welcomed in and they let me try different kinds of tea so I knew what I liked. I very much so enjoyed my experience.
author: Mike V.

description:
It has been seven years since I have reviewed this tea shop.  

After a project meeting on Sat, I just happened to be walking by the store, and decided to purchase my favorite tea for an associate.

I was assisted by Eliza (!?). She was superb in reminding me on the various qualities of certain teas while giving me some shopping ideas.  It was also so nice to talk to Alice, (the owner and the ultra tea expert) again.   They are so pleasant.  

As usual, I was out of there in a shade of a moment (less than eight minutes) and believed that I got the most bang for my buck.. 

[ A Noteworthy Point ] 
They usually have their tea tested for pesticide. I am not sure if other tea shops are doing that.  

If you are a hardcore tea drinker who love quality and enjoys dealing with people who are honest and trustworthy, I highly recommend Red Blossom Tea (RBT) as a "alpha" tea source.

In summary, I respect their business ethics and their commitment to fair pricing.  I give RBT "5 stars plus."
author: Marshal L.

description: Outstanding.   Such amazing selection and super knowledgeable staff.   Feliz knows everything about teas and is the absolute best.    Great tea tasting classes for only $30 a person.  So amazing.  Did I say go, go, go?!?
author: Matt H.

description:
Serious tea drinkers should put Red Blossom on their shortlist of tea shops in San Francisco.  It's one of the few places which will tell you everything about a particular tea, or the "SCOPE": Season, Cultivar, Origin, Picking, and Elevation.  It's not a shop for something like an English Breakfast tea, which isn't really a well-defined product anyhow.  However, if you want to know exactly where and when a tea was picked, this is the type of shop for you.

Note that it's more of a retail shop than a tea room, though you can taste small samples before buying.
author: Lucullus L.

description:
Red Blossom is a fantastic tea shop for the beginning to intermediate tea drinker, and I love that they're conveniently located near my apartment, and near Chinatown where I like to buy other things.  Red Blossom covers your fundamentals, so they'll have great quality selections of the most famous / classic Chinese teas, and starter teaware at reasonable prices.  I can always find an excuse to drop by Red Blossom.

If you're looking for more rare, aged, specialty teas and artisan ceramics and are willing to pay accordingly for them then I recommend Song Tea & Ceramics in Pac Heights (see my review:  http://www.yelp.com/biz/song-tea-and-ceramics-san-francisco-2?hrid=tHJ7jtRMpgPWhAQRGmSChA)  I've found that Song's selection is much smaller and skews heavy on oolongs and a few red teas, so if you like whites or greens you might be disappointed.

The ambience in Red Blossom is clean and modern, and usually pretty busy.  They have 3 gongfu tea setups so they can serve about 12 - 15 people, but it's not the kind of place you can dawdle and taste tea all day.  They do try to discourage you from trying too many teas that are similar to each other, or teas they can tell you won't like.  I wish I could try more teas without feeling guilty but I suppose that's fair, the tastings are for customers who are actually planning to buy and just need to decide which varietal to buy.  If you want to sample the tea ceremony without purchasing tea, you can book a tasting and I think it costs about $10 or $15 per person.



General review of Red Blossom's teas, by type:

---- GREEN TEA ----
All their Dragon Wells have a beautiful buttered toast aroma and flavour.
- Pre-Rain Dragonwell:  bought this one as it's their cheapest Long Jing, finicky to brew but gorgeous clear fresh flavour
- Cloud and Mist:  Fragrant, versatile, cheaper and easier to brew than the PRDW.  Next on my to-buy list.
- Huang Shan Mao Feng:  Not my favourite, but good for people who like more grassy flavour


---- OOLONG TEA ----
- Jin Xuan Winter Sprout:  so buttery and sweet, my partner bought 2oz of this and almost finished it within a week
- Heritage Golden Buddha:  creamy, smoother younger cousin of Da Hong Pao.  This tea has one of my favourite aromas of the teas in my collection (~40 teas)
- Da Hong Pao (Beidou):  they take great pride in the fact that this is a close descendant of the Da Hong Pao mother trees, it was good but I'll need to taste it again before buying
- Wenshan Baozhong:  beautiful light aroma of a greener Taiwanese oolong, but leaves only last about 2 infusions


---- RED / BLACK TEA ----
- Formosa Red, Assam:  gorgeous aroma, smooth, not sweet.  Partner bought this
- Formosa Red #18:  slightly sweeter version of the Assam
- Three Cultivar:  one of my favourites at a reasonable price, but then I'm inclined towards Wuyi oolongs
- Golden Monkey, First Pick:  malty, caramelly, excellent


---- WHITE TEA ----
- Bai Mudan (White Peony) tasted rather old, not the best.  For fresh white teas I love the selections at Teavivre.com


---- TEAWARE ----
The teaware Red Blossom carries is higher quality and thus more expensive than most of the temptingly cheap stuff you can buy online from China (and many other US importers).  The tea trays especially are gorgeous but the stone ones will run you a mind-blowing $400+!  (Makes sense, because the shipping from China alone for a similar stone tray I found on Taobao costs at least US$160.)

I want to call out Red Blossom's basic Jingdezhen Spring / Summer gaiwans, incredible value for US$28.  (I bought one of these for my partner and I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a first gaiwan.)  It is made of very thin but sturdy porcelain, and they actually use those models in the shop for tea tastings every day and they don't seem to chip or stain easily.  For similar prices (US$10 - $24) I've bought 4 gaiwans on Taobao, Ebay and the like, that look good but the material and workmanship are coarser (for example, thicker porcelain that tends to burn the tea or blunt the aroma).  Am saving up to buy another of Red Blossom's plain gaiwans for myself soon.
author: Letitia L.

description: Amazing! You have to try the tea tasting. Alyssa and Felice are so nice and knowledgeable! The highest recommendation possible.
author: Eric S.

description: Tea is very good quality and unlike the big chain, they don't try to upsell me when I make a purchase.
author: Gunnar A.

description: My first time being served at a sit down tea store. I sampled the oolong orange blossom and it was strong to me. Oolong always is but I barely noticed the orange in it. I'm not a tea connoisseur so It was still worth trying. Good service from my host.
author: Miriam T.

description:
If your looking for a wonderful and unique experience See 
Felicia at red blossom. She explained and had a taste some delicious tea . She was so friendly helpful and an expert explaining the various regions and growing environments . The tea was delicious and our experience was the highlight of our trip to San Francisco. I highly recommend making an appointment with Felicia , and spend an hour learning and enjoying tea.
author: michele r.

description: Totally charming purveyor of tea imported from China. Wonderful person served us samples and lessons for a modest charge. We had some sent to Houston and a glasss tea cup brewer
author: Marc G.

description:
**Appointment highly suggestioned. 

This place is a stickler for time. 

I set up an appointment 4 days prior to coming in, but when I arrived, they had my appointment on the wrong day. Nevertheless, they still took me in and told me to pick three variations of tea for the tasting. I asked them , whether we could try more than 3, but they refused saying that time is very limited for them. My friend and I were bummed, but it didn't really matter, because they had such a limited selection of teas anyway. There were 2 teas variety of tea that I haven't tried from there entire store. 

However, as the Red Blossom tea expert carried on, she was very informative about teas, showing us the map of China and pointing out where they were from, explaining exquisite detail on each tea plantation process. I've been to countless tea shop and tasted no less than hundreds, but I did learn something here. :) That's a plus. 

The shop was clean and neat, with the metal tea buckets on the right side from the entrance and the two tasting tables on the left. We were told that since there were limited amount of tasting table, we may had to share the space with two other customers (four chairs per table). We find it slightly ironic, because we made reservations to keep the table to ourselves and the time slot. However, they allowed it so just the two of us preoccupied the table.
author: Lily V.

description:
Very good, they walked me through the teas I was interested in and explained where they came from and what I should expect.

Lots of fresh tea broken down by production season and region. 

Expensive although the service is good, so I'll go there again.
author: A H.

description:
My review is strictly for the teas as I ran in to buy a gift and a bag of Dragon Pearl Jasmine for myself and did not stay to converse or sample.  However, I can say that the service was excellent and swift.

My family thought the Dragon Pearl Jasmine tea was fragrant, smooth and had a delightful after taste.  A little flower went a long way.  We can't wait to try more flavors.

They wrapped the canisters that I purchased as a gift in a cute red bag with bright red tissue paper that made a wonderful presentation and present.  I will definitely be recommending them and looking forward to coming back.
author: Franco L.

description:
My three friends and I had heard several people speak highly of the tea bars in Little China, so we were quite excited when we walked into the Red Blossom Tea Company. 

Unfortunately, right from the moment we entered, the service was snippy and abrasive. They refused to let us try anything but the one batch of tea they had already brewed, and unfortunately, that batch was only barely luke warm and so incredibly watered down that we could barely detect its flavors. 

When we asked if they had any "stronger" flavors, the lady seemed extremely harried by the request. We left shortly after, and found a MUCH better tea tasting shop just a few doors down the block.
author: Jassmine R.

description: I have heard about this place from a friend.  In March when I went to SF for vacation, I decided I had to pay a visit.  Alice is super friendly and very knowledgeable about tea. She made us feel at home, having tea chatting with a friend.  We tried a couple Taiwanese Oolong tea - they were very good, probably the best we are able to get our hands on without having to go to Taiwan ourselves!  I will definitely visit again when I'm in the area.  For now, I'll have to order online.
author: Jennifer L.

description: My husband and I stopped in seeking a respite and got a phenomenal education and experience from Felice, who sat with us for several cups of a sampler of several teas. Clearly the owner and employees know their craft, and even though we're regular tea drinkers, we learned a great deal. I look forward to returning and learning more!
author: Kenlyn M.

description:
I just ordered tea online from this company and I am very disappointed. I love tea. Lapsang tea is a strong robust black tea. When I get it from other places it only takes a small amount of leaves and they can be re-steeped several times before they are spent. Unfortunately the Lapsang tea I just got from Red Blossomm Tea is the weakest I have ever tried. I had wondered why the teas I purchased from them were so much cheaper, now I know why :( 

UPDATE: I just tried the second tea from my order, Tung Ting. It is my favorite oolong. The one they sent me is not as good as the previous one I have. This one is much weaker. Not happy with their teas.
author: Abigail L.

description:
Really good tea experience. Very patient and informative host, and she even offered to give us an extra for free, although we declined.

The tea was extremely high quality and tasty. Would definitely come again
author: Yanir R.

description: Cute tea room. Tea sample was a sweet ceremony. Alice is entertaining! And of course the teas are fabulous!
author: Lillian H.

description: The young lady who "helped" us was extremely pompous. When we asked about a tea, she quoted a price of $800.00 an ounce and told us "We are like fine wines, we don't sell Sangria."  Other customers were having samples and getting educated by staff. Was the lady who spoke to us implying that because I look Latina, I can not afford their tea? I stated 3 times that we could buy some but she walked away. This was such a sad situation, so my husband and I left without tea.
author: Susan D.

description:
Checked out Red Blossom Tea Company in SF Chinatown.  It's a small shop that holds tons of teas from Taiwan & other places I think.

I got to try Dong Pian (Winter Sprout), 2012 iced.  It's naturally sweet & tasted really good.   

Some ladies were doing a tea tasting to find out what they wanted to buy next.  I tagged along & sat next to them.  The water was kept at 195 degrees.  We tried a bunch of teas:

Monkey Picked Tieguanyin
Organic Dragon Pearl Jasmine
Sparrow's Beak
Huang Zhi Xiang (Orange Blossom)
Heritage Beidou (Grand Scarlet Robe) 

I ended up getting the Dong Pian (Winter Sprout) 2012 a 2oz sample is $33!

Charged it.
author: Ann L.

description: Simply the best tea. The prices can be high, but the quality and taste ends up being totally worth it. As I mentioned a while back, they do charge $30 if you want 4 samples, but skip that and just seriously buy some. They will let you sample it if you have intent to purchase. Start with the monkey pick, delicious!
author: Jonathan U.

description: My friend and I were on a mission to find this place. We walked by it once but found it on the way back. Be careful when looking for it, because it's very easy to miss. The second you step inside, you're entranced by the amazing aroma of all the teas! The man who helped us was really nice (didn't catch his name but he had blondish hair). Hey have a huge selection of teas and I ended up purchasing the Jasmin holiday box. It can get a little pricey so just be prepared to make it rain in that store. Enjoy, fellow tea lovers!
author: Tati N.

description:
If you are looking for an exceptional cup of Chinese tea, look no where else! I purchased hundreds dollar worth of tea from them and never disappointed. Their price are high but not unreasonable (Given you get high quality tea). I bought tea at malindao street at beijing China, and found the price is almost comparable ( I did bargain hard in beijing and know how to distinguished high quality tea)  I also found that their pottery is also comparable to those in malindao street. 
beware though if you like sweetened tea, or any bubble tea, this is not the place for you. This is an old school, pure tea experience shop!
They do have good chai tea selection!
author: Dan A.

description: Extensive selection of high quality teas... but pricey.  Think of them like wine and it will help you cope with the cost of the price. Staff very well informed and provides excellent tastings.
author: Sam V.

description: I went there not knowing what to expect based upon reviews on Yelp.  The shop is located in China town.  The staff was very good and explained the various teas and provided recommendations based upon the tea that I like.  This was very helpful in that I've never been in a Chinese tea shop before.  I left with a number of samples and will be able to reorder on line those that I like.  I'd highly recommend this shop.
author: Rick F.

description: I stumbled upon this place when I visited SF for the first time eight years ago. They have fabulous teas and superb service. I come by to stock up every year when I visit family for the holidays. Their jasmine pearls are a staple- the leaves can be brewed multiple times and still yield delicious tea. I love serving their blossoming teas when company comes over- so beautiful in a clear pot! The teas all smell so good and taste even better. Can't go wrong with whatever you choose, truly.
author: Princess U.

description: The staff here is very friendly and the food came fast. The place is nice and clean, a good place to stop for a drink or a quick meal.  Although food is good but a little pricy.
author: Doroncy W.

description:
We had an INCREDIBLE experience at Red Blossom Tea Co. this past weekend. Alice hosted our tea tasting experience; and, as the owner's daughter, she is SO SO knowledgeable about all things tea! I love taking high tea English-style with all the pretty silverware & pastries, and also drink "tea" on a day-to-day basis. Alice opened my eyes to the world of authentic, high-quality teas. For example, I learned that herbal teas are not really teas in the traditional sense, since they are mostly just flowers and herbs steeped in hot water. Also, the English tradition of taking tea usually calls for adding cream and sugar/honey to your tea, which, if the tea is of high quality, ruins the experience and masks the tea's true character and beauty. 

Alice took great time and care in explaining the different kinds of tea to my husband and me (white & green, oolong, & black teas). Very informative & enlightening! I love wine and have a fairly educated palette, so Alice used lots of wine references for me to relate to, since tasting wine and tasting tea are similar experiences. She also introduced us to teas aged for decades, which I fell in love with!

Skip all those phony "free tea tasting" places you see in Chinatown, and come taste the real thing at Red Blossom Tea Company! I'm so glad we did; it was so worth it!

Note: We visited in the late afternoon on a Saturday in early spring (the day before the Chinese New Year festival). We were the only couple having a tea tasting at the time, and though people came into the shop and made purchases, I felt like we had a very personalized experience. The shop did not feel crowded and I did not feel rushed at all.
author: Victoria G.

description: I am totally in love with their Pre-rain Dragonwell. I used to always get Dragonwell from Teavana or Davids, but Red Blossom's is superior. Some of their teas are very expensive but others run about what higher quality teas are elsewhere. Staff is very knowledgable and helpful, but haven't been overly generous with tea samples like other tea shops in Chinatown. Definitely give them a try though, very good tea!
author: Mylie T.

description:
Absolutely love this place! I've been coming here ever since they opened, as they were our tea vendor when I managed Dragon Well on Chestnut St. Although their tea selection may be smaller than many of the other stores in Chinatown, the quality outweighs and outperforms any other option nearby. I'm always blown away by how knowledgeable the staff is, from where the tea is grown, temperature conditions, harvest times, post-harvest preparation and serving techniques.

My absolute favorites are the Moroccan mint, lychee black and Dragon Pearl Jasmine. As a treat, I'll sometimes throw in a blossoming bud as well.

Even though I no longer live in San Francisco, I always stop by Red Blossom on every visit to restock my tea supply. Yes, you can order online, but there's nothing like being able to smell and taste the amazing aromas in person.
author: David N.

description: I used to own a tea house and therefore am extremely picky about tea. I stop at this place every time I come to San Fran. In particular their oolong selection is excellent. They also do a nice tasting to let you select which varieties you want to buy. Highly recommend them.
author: Greg B.

description:
BREWING THE BAY: Chinese and Taiwanese loose leaf teas, gongfu teaware

Red Blossom is tied with Aroma Tea Shop as the best tea shop in the city for Chinese and Taiwanese loose leaf teas. They don't have as overwhelming an amount of selection as Aroma, but the quality is just as high. There is also plenty of free tea sampling to be had. 

Alice and Ada are very nice and clearly passionate about what they do. Alice, who now runs Red Blossom (it's a family-owned business), is the type of tea connoisseur who could spend hours talking about pu-erh and oolong if you let her. Through consultations with her, I decided to pick up a few ounces of charcoal-roasted oolong from Taiwan and some Lapsang Souchong for tea cooking. Fun fact: Lapsang Souchong really isn't meant for drinking in the world of Chinese teas--it's mainly used for cooking. Who's making Szechuan tea-smoked duck in the near future? Meeeeeeee! :)

I've visited pretty much all the tea shops in Chinatown and this one stands miles above the others in terms of service (friendly), knowledge (robust), decor (clean, modern and simple), quality (high) and prices (fair and actually cheaper than Aroma in several instances). Don't be put off by its location. It's anything but a tourist trap.
author: Josephine L.

description: We've always had great service from the staff working at Red Blossom.  They listen to us describe our tastes in tea and what we've liked from previous purchases, they then make suggestions and provide sample tastes.  I also appreciate the staff sharing their own views and preferences on the different teas in the shop and their techniques for brewing.  I like the selection very much, interesting and diverse varieties from PRC and Taiwan.  They'd be perfect if they also stocked interesting tea from India and Japan but I give them five stars for defining their niche and executing within that niche at a very high level.
author: M W.

description:
Now that we got all the shopping out of the way, sit down, relax and enjoy some tea in a charming tea house. The entire staff is extremely knowledgeable about all of their teas and will not hesitate to answer any questions that you might have. They also have a sampling station so that you can try different teas before buying. This stop can prove to be a relaxing, educational experience


(IF FOLLOWING MY "CHINATOWN FOODIE TOUR,  this is a great place to temporarily escape the busy streets of Chinatown and take a breather)
author: Linda H.

description:
The best selection of Oolongs, with Chinese names (not rebranded).

Five stars for the tea, but not so hot on service, try to rush you out the door after one tasting, even if you buy what you taste.  Invent reasons you shouldn't try a tea.

If you like Oolongs, go and insist on multiple tastings. Being firm overcomes their get-the-f***-out attitude.

edit: I am afraid they won't serve me since my pic is on this review, so I'm bumping it to four stars. I think my fear of not being served justifies the increase. Also, the Oolong they said I wouldn't be able to taste after trying some strong ones actually does not taste good. So I should have listened to them. So four stars. Ah hell, I'll give it five.

Seriously the tea is kinda pricey but its really good.
author: Russell X.

description:
Coming here made me realize how much of a novice I am in my knowledge of teas. I felt like I was a little kid in a candy store, wide-eyed with the assortment of teas and accessories they offered, and the decor inside matched the mood. You're not going to find your sugar-filled Kool-aid iced teas here; it's nothing but the best and authentic teas in it's most purest form.

The staff was very helpful (I think they saw my deer-in-headlights look when I was walking around lol), and I was even offered to join in on a tea sampling with a random newlywed couple. I saw/learned how to properly brew and taste tea for it's hint of flavors. 

Take my money. Now.
author: Marc M.

description:
Great tea shop! I took the time to sit down and try three or four different teas with absolutely no pressure. 

They have a really solid range of teas and accessories ranging from the affordable and every day to rare and high end. Worth a visit for sure and prices are fair for the quality of tea.
author: Morgan S.

description:
Red Blossom really changed the way I saw tea.  No wonder why the tea bags bought at the grocery store (anything in tea bags for that matter) can be so bitter - I am told those leaves are the just bits and pieces leftover from the tea houses!  Just look how supple and fresh these tea leaves look after steeping, not like the dry, crackly bits and fragments you normally get: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZG0CRrkc9i-AGnea3CeWYw?select=RmcjO6uz5YCaKdZpQH5Dgw 

I did not know that the loose leaf teas carried by stores like this can be steeped several times.  I love jasmine tea and I fell in love with their "blossoming" type (also called flowering or blooming teas).  Tea leaves wrapped with dried flowers take the form of a bulb for drying and storage, the little bundle of leaves and petals unfurl and "blossoms" and have an amazing aromatic fragrance, looks so pretty and such a joy to sip on!  Here's how it looks in my personal steeping vessel, also bought at Red Blossom:  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZG0CRrkc9i-AGnea3CeWYw?select=sRTGEYFm62TGqMmVWQXNGw

The folks here are really nice, so well versed and are always happy to give a lesson and tasting.  They also have boxed sets that have a sampling of a little bit of everything, great as a starter kits or gifts.  Every time we plan a trip to Chinatown, we always have to make a stop here.  Whether you are into tea or not, the experience will really resonate with you.  I encourage you to drop in!
author: Teresa P.

description:
Wow, I should have written a review long before this. My apologies.

Alice has been the owner since her parents retired and she has kept the family tradition intact. Her brother Peter now sells very high end teas at a different shop in San Francisco, but Alice has kept the original shop the way her parents ran it. It was through Alice that I became a full-time tea addict, and I am forever grateful. I have probably bought about half of the teas on the shelves by now.

This shop sells mostly teas sourced from Taiwan, but also has a selection of Japanese greens, if I remember correctly. They also have flavored teas like Jasmine and those fun flowering teas. I gave a friend some black tea flavored with rose petals and it was a huge hit. They have teas at every price point, but the prices are definitely going to be higher than the teabags at the store because you're not getting junk. 

I've never made an appointment for a tea tasting. That said, I've had tea tastings here many times and it's one of the reasons I stay pretty loyal to this shop because this is how I ended up learning about many different teas. Try asking for a tasting when they're not busy. 

Great place to venture out into the world of teas. 

My preference tends to lean toward sweet, buttery, creamy, yet citrusy. That's why I'm really into their greens and lightly oxidized oolongs lately, so take what I have to say below with that in mind.

My faves right now are: "Our Finest Dragonwell" (the priciest one, but that one goes fast because it's super buttery and rich and amazing, totally worth it.) 

Also, I am really into their high mountain oolongs right now. My daily tea choice is usually their Wenshan Baozhong; this one is very sweet and creamy, not as watery and citrusy as I've had elsewhere. My other daily tea is their Alishan (very buttery last year) and the Fu Shou Shan (despite the fruity, floral overtones this has a nice backbone that I typically just drink by itself, no food).  Love the Lishan as well. I love their Heritage Grand Scarlet Robe Wuyi oolong (very dark, charcoal roasted oolong). If I recall correctly, this is the one that someone suggested drinking while eating a chocolate cake. I haven't tried that yet.

Assams are typically Indian teas, but I really like the Taiwanese sourced "assams" that they have here. I really love the Organic Formosa Red assam (sweet, rich, thought it was an excellent accompaniment to a single butter cookie)  and the Native Cultivar Mi Xiang one (from the word "honey" in the name, it's definitely sweeter, yet I'm kind of partial to the less sweet version). The Three Cultivar Red looks intriguing, but I haven't tried it yet.

Maybe if I win the lottery, I'll go check out Peter's shop, or maybe I'll just stay here.
author: Choco L.

description: Tea to try for free. All of the teas are in large metal containers (compared to the clear glass ones at most other places) so you can't see the quality until you request it. Once opened though, a nice aroma is usually released. They will gladly make you cup before you buy. Quality stuff is sold here.
author: Nam B.

description: This place is great! Not only is the variety of teas available gigantic, but the servers are excellent. They are very professional and friendly, telling us the benefits of each tea an whatnot. Sitting in and simply trying different tea leaves was fun, and we ended up ordering about a pound of Oolong with ginseng powder
author: Tal M.

description:
Despite being on Grant Street, Red Blossom is the antithesis of a tourist trap.

The amount of tea here is downright daunting. Should I get a gunpower blend, or is the phoenix oolong right for me? There's a massive selection here, and it is easy to get drawn to browsing the shelves and reading about each style. 

The place is clean and professional, but the prices can be downright expensive for some of the rarer blends. Then again, these teas are the real deal, and can beat the everloving crap out of store-bought bags six ways from Sunday.
author: Casey S.

description: Shopping for tea at Red Blossom was a delightful experience.  I went in looking for some nice tea to give as a New Year's gift to a friend from China.  I wanted to be sure that I got something nice.  I was invited to sit down to join the proprietor and one of her regular customers as they tasted tea.  She was very gracious with her explanations.  The tea was delicious.  I left with two delicious teas in a nice tin, plus the confidence that I was giving my friend quality tea that will be appreciated.
author: J E.

description: This store has been passed down to the daughter.  Will be interesting to see how it moves forward.  The other sibling pictured in the main photo is starting his own tea company at http://www.songtea.com/
author: Erik H.

description:
wide selection of tea and accessories, but not overwhelming.

Unlike the other shops on Chinatown, this one is geared towards Western shopping styles and expectations: not bargaining, no needing to check for authenticity. They sell the representative  best here, relative to each item's price price point. 

I came in hoping for expert, uncrushed personal help. Many of the shops I had previously visited were rushed, and clearly attempting to sell items which were not of the best quality. Here I was poured a cup to sample before purchasing, and left satisfied and confident with my purchase.

I feel that this place is worth the trip if you live in the South Bay. So is Aroma Tea Shop on Sixth& Clement (specialists in Taiwan)
author: Ethan K.

description:
Very good tea at good prices. Tung Ting is great for an everyday tea. White teas is great for evening. I can drink it after 6pm and it will give me clarity and energy, but when it is time for sleep it does not keep me up.

Only complaint here is the service. Other places just down the street will offer you samples. We have spent over an hour tasting many teas at these other places. Not here. Once I was offered a taste of some iced tea they keep near the register. 

We buy tea from here all the time and last time I asked if I could get the white tea but asked for if they could please separate it into to bags because I wanted to give one half to my friend. (I am trying to get her hooked on it, too. We are both law students and need all the good energy we can get.) The girl said no! Just flat out no! Did not even offer to give me a bag so I could separate it myself! Really?! WTF?!!!

I had never seen her working there before. Maybe she was new and could not do me the favor,..

I will be coming back but only for the tea. If you want a tea tasting experience go elsewhere. Three stars for the tea.
author: Yesenia D.

description: Love this place. I wish they would bring back the Vanilla Orchid black tea, though. It's my favorite.
author: Samantha S.

description:
I believe Amanda was the person that educated me on tea during my visit.  She couldn't have been nicer and more patient.

I simply didn't realize tea is a process and not a bag of something you throw in hot water.

She spent time walking me through there many varieties as well as the different stages of varieties.  The real focus was on green and white teas.  We talked about the similarities of tea harvesting and olive oil pressing.  We also discussed how to bring out the sugars properly in tea.

Amanda offered and showed me how to make a proper cup of tea.  The tea pot couldn't have been more than 6 ounces, the glasses 1-2 ounces, and she did not bring the water to a boil.  The tea we had was a little beyond tap water hot.  She explained how to avoid bitter tea and most important showed that tea is an event and should be a slow and relaxing process.

I'll be ordering from them in the future.  Great store.
author: Chris M.

description:
Being a tea lover there are several tea shops I like to support in Berkeley, but when I want to take visitors to my favorite tea shop, this is where I like to take them and here's why.

The owners are excited about tea, very friendly, knowledgeable, good humored, smart, and not at all pushy. They love to share their knowledge and traditions of tea and they've created a really nice environment in the middle of China Town where you feel like you're in a Zen space than the typical (and fun) stores in chinatown where every inch of space is crammed with things.

They also carry the most wonderful tea servers and the quality of their tea is excellent. I've been shopping here since a friend told me about the place in 2005 and my favorite tea is the Lishan, Formosa Oolong.
author: Andrea Y.

description:
These people seriously know their tea and can pretty much answer any questions you have! 

So I love drinking tea and more than that I love learning about it too. I came here not knowing much about tea except for the fact that it's a bunch of leaves you steep and drink. I pretty much went up to one of the sales women empty handed with no clue where to even start. By time I went out the door I felt as if I were given a free one hour lesson on tea. Yes the tea is slightly more expensive than your crappy 99 cent tea bags but hey it's worth it! So put that earl grey artificial fruit flavor tea down and give this place a try!
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
While exploring Chinatown I suddenly decided a trip to a tea house would be quite enjoyable. I quickly grabbed my iPhone and loaded my Yelp app- which lead me right to Red Blossom. I was instantly intrigued by the walls lined with tea, beautiful handcrafted tea sets for sale and the overwhelming aromas. I instantly saw the sign for tea tastings so my friend and I participated.


We sat with a soft spoken yet eloquent and learned Chinese woman who reminded us both of Many Moore. She talked all about tea, asked us our preferences then gave suggestions. We tasted a white tea, a black tea and a jasmine tea. Each tea was brewed using a different method to show all the different ways it could be brewed. Each time she took the care and consideration to allow us to taste several different times, re-steeping the tea at least 3 times each.  My favorite was the black tea- bold, rich and full. We enjoyed the experience so much that I took home one of the handmade glass tea pots used in our tasting. It was such a charming yet informative little experience and I highly recommend it to everyone, from the tea novice to the tea master.
author: Sheena M.

description: Great tea selection, knowledgeable staff, affordable prices. What more can you ask for? I have drank lots of greens, oolongs in my life, so I thought the other ones were the most interesting, including Moroccan Mint and Lemongrass Ginger. You can tell their mint tea leaves are much different from the other ones. Also, the Lychee Black was really nice, I learned how to aerate tea in your mouth to experience the subtle flavors more intensely. Basically, just suck air into your mouth while you have some tea in it still, and let the liquid bubble in your mouth. Pre-packaged 2 ounce bags are available for purchase once you choose your teas. Containers are sold separately. They also sell pretty cute tea sets which a bit more pricey.
author: Jess C.

description:
If you're like me and was wondering whether to go here or to Vital Leaf down the street, go to Vital Leaf. 

Dropped by here on the hunt for some tea. Place is very nicely laid out, but the service was underwhelming. I was the only person in the entire store on a quiet Wednesday afternoon, but other than a brief, disinterested hello and an offer to "smell any teas I'm interested in," I got no help. 

I went down the street to Vital Leaf and had a much better experience, including having a chance to sample 7 different teas.
author: Daniel S.

description:
This is one of the best tea shops! I went in here just to peruse their selection, I purchased the Organic Dragon Pearl Jasmine tea & the Dragonwell Chamomile green tea.

Ada was the rep who helped us. She was incredibly knowledge and explained the teas and processes simply but as if it were a science. She even sat down and brewed tea for us to let us try the teas to make sure we liked them. She was extremely helpful and her service was top notch.

Thank you Ada and Red Blossom tea for sending us home as happy customers!
author: Collette C.

description:
My friend and I had an enjoyable and educational experience at this tea shop.  We were both scouting out the teas shops on Grant Street but found most of the shops to be filled with pushy sales people.  Red Blossom had helpful staff that was knowledgeable and passionate about their product; its great to encounter people who love their job.

The $30 tea tasting included 3 different types of tea with three serving per tea types for to 4 people.  Throughout the tasting we were given information on tea harvesting, tea brewing, and  various aspects that made the tea unique.  

Each type of tea was available for purchase in different quantities depending on the amount of money you want to spend.

I highly recommend you try this tea shop.
author: Chin C.

description: Time for an update (7 years, later).  I'm still a faithful customer.  It doesn't get better than this!
author: Debbie T.

description:
This place was awesome an no pressure.  We came in unsure of what to expect.  There is a giant wall of tea canisters that you invited to open and smell at your leisure.  The helpful employees explained the arrangement of the teas, as well as TONS of information about the individual canisters we picked up.  While we were tea sniffing, another employee brought us a sample of a cold brewed tea (long brewed, kind of like sun tea), that was excellent.  Then a few minutes later she invited us to participate in an informal Chinese style tea ceremony where we tried a lighter style oolong and conversed about tea.  

We ended up spending about half an hour and $25 here, but never felt pressure to buy - these people are just really excited about tea and want to share their love of their excellent product.  They also have tea in all price ranges.  We bought a middle of the road tea for our middle of the road tea palates - I believe the bag of tea has about 32 servings in it for that cost.  Some were as inexpensive as $7 or $8 for that amount, and some were in the hundreds of dollars.  It just depends on what you are looking for, and the employees will be happy to help you find something suitable in whatever range you are working with.
author: Heather H.

description:
Had a strange experience here. I've been to a couple of tea places and am a fan of tea. I'd looked this place up on yelp and was excited.

Unfortunately, my friend and I felt that the service was a little strange. The lady helping us did not seem particularly warm or friendly. When we asked if we could try one of the tea's, she said that they don't do brewing here because "the whole place would smell like it" (which seems a little odd for a tea place to be worried about..but hey). She then said that it tastes like it smells. 

My friend then said she liked green tea and was hoping the employee would provide some recommendations but she just told my friend to open the canisters to smell the tea. 

I'm not sure if they were a little cold/not as friendly to us because it seemed like we weren't going to be huge customers, or if it was a bad day. It seems like the service is a little inconsistent (seeing the reviews below).

We ended up going a few blocks to Vital Tea and had a great time (and sampled a few teas there), and purchased tea there.
author: Yan K.

description:
RBTC made my day - almost hidden among the many touristy places in Chinatown, it suddenly reveals itself as a passage into another world of elegant teas. Minimalistic in its design the place focuses on the essential - a quiet oasis amidst a lot of visual and acoustic noise. 

Just entering and finding myself in this environment made me happy. And finding the Lapsang Souchong - which tonight turned out to be truly great - resulted in the solution for a personal mystery -  why Chinese supermarkets don't sell Lapsang Souchong: The amazingly patient young lady who helped me explained it with simplicity: Nobody drinks it in China - it's more a Russian thing - in China it is used to add taste to roasted duck dishes at best.

'll be back soon!

-------
Packaging of the tea and presentation is excellent - also great for presents.
author: Flo B.

description: I like it.  Young lady was very helpful and provided good advice to someone who is not experienced with tea.  I am happy with the tea she recommended and I bought.  I will order from web site in future.  I got Keemun tea.  Nice flavor and mild.
author: T B.

description: Absolutely amazing experience. All of the employees were EXTREMELY friendly and knowledgeable about tea. I tasted a myriad of tea, from a bi luo chun to an aged baozhong from 1982. The store is absolutely beautiful and clean cut, and each canister of tea is clearly labeled with detailed information, everything from the specific mountain and region in which the tea was grown and harvested in to the production date. I ended up leaving with 2oz of charcoal roasted tungting oolong. This is one of those teashops where the employees objective isnt just to force Tea and random accessories down your throat. The people here are really passionate about tea and rather than doing the former, they teach customers about methods of tea preparation and culture. Definitely recommend this place to anyone who enjoys tea, from a casual tea drinker to a hardened tea hobbyist!
author: Julian M.

description:
Being of Taiwanese decent I thought for sure I'd know my teas...oh boy was I wrong. 

Red Blossom Tea Company went over the different kinds of teas and where you find them throughout Asia.  We got to sample 2 different teas and was delighted when Alice went over the proper tea brewing process with us...reminded me of how my grandpa use to serve us tea.  They have many varieties of loose leaf teas in the store.  Never thought I'd be that Taiwanese sucker that buys tea in Chinatown...but yes, the experience was so informative and the teas we sampled were great that we bought some tea.  

Overall:  a great tea store in the middle of Chinatown.  Great place to get away from the hustle and bustle of Chinatown to learn about tea.
author: Shirley C.

description:
Good teas. I bought a few different kinds to bring home. In particular, I got an oolong, jasmine, and lychee black. 

The teas are premeasured in specific weights and so I wasn't able to make a strange request. If you're interested, I was buying tea in bulk for me and a friend and asked if I could get the 8 oz split into two 4 oz bags. They weren't able to accommodate that, but provided me with an additional ziploc bag so I could split it myself. Unfortunately, I made a bit of a mess at home, but that was my fault. :) 

The tasting was informative and professional. The rep helping me knew her stuff and made it easy for me to feel like I made the right choice with my purchase.
author: Robin D.

description: This place is wonderful. A great selection of tea, teaware, and very knowledgeable and friendly staff. Alyssa really took the time to help me find the teas that I loved! I will certainly be back!!
author: Ran D.

description: This place is great. The owner is really nice. The owner helps me out with picking out tea almost every week. Since my coworking space is nearby, it means a lot to me to have a great tea place around the corner.
author: Jenny C.

description:
This is a nice date activity.  They let you have a sample of a bunch of teas so you can discover your "tea palate"

If you are very picky about teas this is probably a good spot for you.  

Just know that the teas can get pretty pricey, so make sure you love tea.  If you can't tell a big difference this might not be the place for you.  

I spent too much here.... The tea is good, but i can't tell a big difference between the expensive tea i bought here and some cheaper loose leaf teas my friends gave me.

This place might be super legit, but i'm humbly giving it 3 stars cause i can't tell a big enough difference for the price difference...
author: Steven F.

description: Contrary to one of the previous reviews we were underwhelmed at vital tea leaf and welcomed with open arms at red blossom. They were extremely helpful and their knowledge of tea was impressive . We were positively infused :) .
author: Gavin K.

description:
I really like their teas! They had samples of the Jasmine Sparrow beak and that was amazing!!!

This place is the only place i'll get my tea's from now on
author: -Johnson- N.

description: I used to like shopping here, but lately I feel like they want me in and out as quickly as possible. The newer staff does not seem to want to allow you to taste the tea. I love the tea, but the service makes the experience suboptimal. I think the staff has an overinflated idea of the importance of this shop.
author: Andrew R.

description: We have loved Red Blossom for years, making it a regular stop whenever we go to Chinatown. Yesterday we went here with friends from out of town. The clerk accidentally gave us the wrong tea. When we got home and opened the tea, we realized her mistake. The manager refused to honor our purchase. When we called she said it was our mistake because we should not have left with black tea chai, knowing that we had asked for regular chai. This $20 error on their part has cost them a repeat customer. Their error left this customer unsatisfied with Red Blossom Tea Company. They have little regard for customer loyalty and offer poor customer service. Best of luck to Red Blossom! I recommend buying tea elsewhere. Buyer beware! Red Blossom does not care about customers.
author: Tyler R.

description:
Let me just warn you, once you have their teas you'll never want to shop anywhere else AND you NEVER want a tea bag again. I admit it: I'm spoiled. My coworker took me to that other tea place in the mall in SF, where they sell bulk teas and it just could not compare to the quality and flavor of the teas at Red Blossom- i haven't found any place that can.

Not only are they friendly, knowledgeable, helpful and family-owned but they simply have the best, freshest tea. They have so many different jasmine teas (i thought there was only one kind, but no) you'll never want a tea bag again, ever. 

In comparison to other places I think their prices are reasonable, not overpriced for what you get. 
love the lychee black and the zhi lan xiang-orchid is pretty good too. The smallest amount they let you buy will last a looong time even if you drink it every day.
author: Layla L.

description:
We had a disappointing experience here. We have had great experiences at other tea rooms in Chinatown but wanted to try some new places, so we stopped here on the basis of the positive Yelp reviews. I am sure the tea is wonderful, but I wouldn't know, since we never got to taste it. We tried to get the attention of a saleswoman for about 10 minutes before she acknowledged us at all. When we asked to taste two varieties of tea, she told us to smell them instead, as the tea "tastes like it smells." We asked again if we could taste it, which I don't think is an outlandish request in a tasting room, and she brushed us off. Then she asked us what kind of tea we like and where we normally buy our tea, and when I answered, she walked off without even answering, never to return. I got the distinct impression that her questions were a test we had failed, and that she had decided we were too pedestrian to be worth her time. Despite feeling uncomfortable, we still wanted to taste a few teas, but she never came back, so after standing around like idiots for another few minutes, we left. It's a shame, because some of those teas were intriguing, but I don't need to be treated like I am too dumb to qualify as a customer.

Instead, we walked down the block to Vital Tea, where they were happy to prepare every tea we wanted to taste, and kindly and patently explained to us how to prepare them ourselves. You should go there instead.
author: Julie R.

description:
I have been going to Red Blossom for a couple of years -- I love their variety of Chinese "candies" and other edibles that are stored in containers in the back.  These Chinese candies are the kind that I grew up eating (I'm Chinese) and that my grandma would always get for me as a child.  So if you're into Chinese candies, this is a great place to go if you know your Chinese candies.  

They have a large variety of different teas, arrange on shelves from darks woody teas to the more delicate jasmines.  The staff are very knowledgable about every single kind of tea and can describe the flavor, texture and origin of anything.  It's almost like a museum -- so definitely grab one of the staff and they will be more than happy to give you a "guided tour" of all the tea selections.

The highlight of Red Blossom is their tea demonstration.  It costs $30 for up to 4 people.  And it's worth every penny.  One of the staff sits on a little banquet chair and you sit across from her on a little tea station.  They offer a variety of 6 teas (at least I think it was 6) and you pick 3 to taste test.  The staff member was very (as they all are) well versed in everything about the teas.  For about an hour or so, she showed us how to properly brew each tea and she serves you a little cup of each as she goes along  She steeps each of the 3 teas at least 3 or 4 times which gives you a sense of how the flavor changes with each steeping.  Needless to say, everything I thought I knew about making tea was wrong.  So if you're a fan of tea, this is a great way to learn and really discover how to make that perfect pot of tea.  When I have friends visiting from out of town, I always take them to Red Blossom and sign up for a demonstration.  The gal who guided us was well spoken, elonquent and a charming person.

There are several tea stores in China Town and I think Red Blossom is one of the best -- it's SQUEAKY CLEAN and the staff are always happy to help.  They also have a variety of tea pots/mugs, etc. beautifully packaged that would make great gifts or souvenirs for your out of town guests.  It doesn't stop there -- they also have a decent selection of ginseng roots that range from $28 a pound to almost $500 a pound (these are for the serious ginseng fan) -- it sounds horribly expensive, and it is but these prices for ginseng are market price.

All of their products are market priced -- this is not your discount tea shop.  But it's not terribly expensive so if you're a tea lover, this is the place to go.
author: Paul N.

description: Wow... so dissapointed in this place. Came here with my dad who is an herbalist/acupuncturist and has been a tea enthusiast for years. Let me start by saying they had 6 people working, were not crowded, and told us they were too understaffed to provide us tea tasting, yet they provided it for 4 other people who came in! Pretty rude. The place is snooty and uncomfortable. The staff is overdressed, and the tea is overpriced. We went a few doors down instead to Vital Tea Leaf and spent over $200 after the staff generously served us about 10 types of tea, including their best (and btw Red Blossom said they do not sample their top shelf tea) and taught us all about the teas and how to prepare/serve them. If you want a perfect experience walk about a block more to 905 Grant and visit Vital Tea instead- much more welcoming, high quality, and fair prices.
author: Jessica S.

description:
It's a temple of tea.

My family lived in Great Britain for a number of years so I'm more familiar with Black teas like Earl Grey.  I will admit I have a lot to learn about other types of teas. The staff at Red Blossom Tea was very patient with me as I stared longingly at the many containers of amazing teas.  Their English is better than mine so we had no issue with communication.  I asked so many questions my throat began to get dry.  I was even allowed to open the container tops to take in the aroma of each of their offerings.  Intoxicating.
One of the staffers brought me a sample of a tea in a small ceramic cup. They had just brewed it.  Such a nice touch and a fine selection.  I savoured every drop.  My throat was soothed. 
I found they had a large number of regulars who came through the door who greeted the staff and seemed to have a standing order for specific teas.  It's terrific to have such a loyal following in such a touristy area.  
I was a little overwhelmed with the sheer variety of selections and I found myself reading all the details on each tea canister.  I decided to focus on tea which would be something I could have at bed-time.  One of the staffers (sorry I forgot her name) pointed to the low caffeine tea containers and the Rooibos in particular.  They still had a very large selection and it still took me some time to select.  I settled on the Rooibos.  It's a South African tea that contains a high amount of Antioxidants and a very low level of Caffeine.  Great recommendation.  
I got a nod of approval from the lady who rang up my purchase so I felt pretty good about what I bought.  I'll bring my friends here.  Terrific Place.
author: Webb P.

description:
The only problem I have here is when I have to decide what to buy. My family and friends have a running bet each time I go here on whether I will spend 100, 200, 300, or 400 (and sometimes, they even put me on a budget).

To those out there who are coming here to get "medicinal teas"...my suggestion would be to go to the tourist trap tea stores down the street. They have teas that are not as good quality and they will tell you anything you want to hear (I know this because I went into one of these stores and it just confirmed that I will stick with Red Blossom).

Red blossom is for those who truly want a quality tea. If you tell them, what you are used to drinking, they will find a tea that might suit your taste buds and they will brew it for you to taste. The service that I always have is great and I feel so relaxed when I visit.
author: Lynelle M.

description:
I am disappointed at this place which is recommended by the Lonely Planet.  The assortment and branding of the teas are OK, but what I find disappointing is the attitude of the shop owners.  As I understand, this shop is run by a couple.  The husband was OK, didn't talk much though.  The wife was quite passive aggressive and gave me a blind eye when I asked her a question.  The most friendly staff was a young girl who should be their employee who had to be nice anyways.  What's more, I was not offered any tasting although I bought two different teas from them.   

Regarding the price, it is very expensive.  Most of the teas are around $20-30/two ounces (or about 50g).  Some of the prices can be as high as early $40/two ounces.  I bought the best Japanese green tea in Japan Town, which cost me only about $18/200g.  That is to say the teas here is at least 4 times more expensive. I understand tea prices vary a lot depending on the type, the origin, the quality and the season.  But I seriously doubt that the teas sold here justify such a high price.  I am happy to spend more for the tasting experience, the knowledgable and friendly staff etc, but unfortunately these were just absent in my visit.  I really cannot recommend this place at all and I won't go back myself.
author: G C.

description:
Walking by, the Red Blossum Tea Company can be quite intimidating for the average patron.  I had the pleasure of visiting this little educational interactive display courtesy of a Wok Wiz Chinatown tour.  

Alice proceeded to explain the differences of the tea that the Red Blossum Tea Company offered and presented a wonderful sensory image as she steeped what would be a nice sample of their tea.  Explaining that she and her brother took over the family business and gave their store an HGTV remodel, you can see and appreciate the personal service that has made this family business such a success.

After enjoying a few cups, you'll feel inclined to want to purchase a few bags of loose tea for your home consumption.  And if you're concerned that loose tea from a tea company will be expensive, think again!  Sure, they have some very expensive (out of my budget) type tea, but they also offer some moderately priced ones as well as some inexpensive ones.  Add one of their tea storing cans to your purchase and it makes an even nicer gift!     

I would definitely recommend Red Blossum Tea Company as one of those places you must visit as a tourist or local of San Francisco.  You'll not only learn a thing or two about tea, but you'll also be embarrassed about all those other boxed tea bags you've been buying at your local grocery store.  It's about time one learns to better appreciate how tea should be consumed.  (I'm embarrassed that I only discovered this place now!)

If you can't visit the store, check out their website.  It's quite detailed with descriptions of tea and you can order it all online as well.
author: Teri C.

description: Tea, tea, tea everywhere. These people really know their tea. Seriously, I've never seen so many teas before or since. Always come here when I'm in San Francisco.
author: Christopher S.

description:
My husband and I went there yesterday and I can not say it better than any of the reviews here. We were a little intimidated at first but that quickly went away. Aida(sorry if that is the wrong spelling) was very helpful and taught us a lot about loose teas. We even had our own oersonal brewing lesson. It was very interesting to see the taste difference between the first time the tea is steeped and the fourth time. As I write this I an sipping my second steeping of their Emperor Pu-erh 1998. 
We can't wait to go back.
author: Michele V.

description:
My daughter Jasmyn gave me a tea tasting at the Red Blossom for my birthday and yesterday at 3p.m. was the appointed hour.  It was a beautiful experience.  If you like tea this is the place to be.

We were fortunate to have Alice guide us through the 3 teas my daughter chose: a dragonwell green, a Formosa oolong, and a tieguanyin oolong. Although green tea is my morning tea most of the time, oolong is my special treat tea.  Alice explained the different terrior and the different treatment of each tea once it is harvested.  Jasmyn has brought me back many teas from her travels in Thailand and Nepal, but the Red Blossom teas are the best I've ever tasted.

As important as the quality of the tea is the correct brewing.  Alice explained what she was doing and why during the multiple infusions; all done effortlessly as she was describing her trips to the different tea growing areas.  It was a delightful and delicious education.

Tip:  Avoid the noon rush and consider booking later in the afternoon when the store is not crowded.
author: joanne c.

description:
I came into Red Blossom Tea a few days ago after a very long day at work, knowing that this would be just the place to cheer me up.  I'd been in more of a hurry the last time I came in, but this time I had more time, and Amanda was happy to sit down with me and let me taste a few teas.

I learned a ton in my 45-minute visit.  Amanda explained the difference between all their types of oolong teas, among others, and showed me the best way to make a quality cup of tea in a gaiwan.

It was a wonderful experience, far more than just a great place to buy quality tea.  They also have a wide price range of teas, and they'll be happy to let you taste any so you know exactly what you're buying.  I ended up getting the **San Lin Xi, Spring 2010 oolong tea** that is an absolutely amazing high-altitude Taiwanese oolong tea, and the **Formosa Red No. 18** black tea that I tasted at Frog Hollow at the Ferry Building, and which is the reason I even decided I needed to track down Red Blossom.

Those tea names, however, may likely be irrelevant by the time you may read this review, because their teas change with each harvest of tea.  However, I'm confident that Red Blossom is *always* going to have delicious, complex teas, and while I will mourn the end of my Formosa Red No. 18 the day it runs out, I'll find a new one to love at Red Blossom.

Come in here when you've got time to do a proper tasting, and you'll have an unforgettable experience!!!
author: David W.

description:
Good selection of teas divided by region and elevation. 
The owner was very nice and gave us a good lesson about tea brewing and proper techniques, however they are kinda stngy with the amounts of different varieites you can sample, one or two and then they start making up excuses about this and that. Tea cups and porcelain pots are way overpriced.
author: Giorgio B.

description: Really impressive selection of teas, and lots of expertise.  A true treat.
author: Mel G.

description: Was in a couple weeks ago, made a special trip just to buy tea from Red Blossom, have brought tea here previously, several times, love the hibiscus tea, was greeted by a woman that wasn't too interested in answering any questions my friend had about green teas, she was quite aloof, I finally after much frustration approached other lady, who was great, helpful and knowledgeable, the owner husband was changing lightbulbs, the owner needs to learn some basic how to greet, be helpful to prospective customers. She was very very rude. Time to find a new tea shop!!!
author: Sammie J.

description:
This place is serious about their tea. Went on a pretty crowded afternoon, but a staff member took the time to approach us and explained how to smell the teas and how they were organized on the wall. It doesn't seem like they give free samples, unless you buy a certain kind of tea and then they will show you how to brew it. 

The price tags were pretty shocking and I didn't buy anything, but it definitely seems like you pay for the quality.
author: J E.

description: What a wonderful find. We did tea tasting and took home a couple of selections. Small family owned business.
author: E M.

description:
If you are a tea addict, a tea newbie, or a tea scholar, this is definitely the place you want to be spending your time and money.

When you enter the shop you will be greeted by a simple and humble looking shop. On one side there is a wall of tea containers that contain a plethora of tea leaves where you can pop off the top to smell and gaze at the leaves. On the other side are all the fun and authentic tea accessories such as fascinating tea sets, tea trays, gaiwans, measuring tools, etc. 

The employees also make the experience fun as they are very knowledgable and helpful when trying to find a tea. Even if you are new to tea and wish to pick it up as a hobby, the employees are very patient and extremely passionate about tea. My best friends is a tea fanatic, whereas I am just a light tea drinker, but every time we go to Red Blossom there is a little something that both of us can enjoy. 

For those of you who are interested in trying out the tea leaves prior to buying them, they have two small tables set up where they will provide a proper tea tasting. Employees explain the process as they create the tea and will share with you proper heating temperatures and steeping time. Don't be afraid to ask questions either because they will always give you a very detailed answer.

They also have a website that contains all the teas that come in from China and Taiwan so you can also order it to have it shipped to your home. However, if you ever get the chance to go to Chinatown, you must stop by this tea shop and experience a little piece of tea heaven. Don't be fooled by the simplicity of the shop, it is full of quality items just waiting to be discovered. :)
author: Alfred B.

description:
I went here looking for some potent loose teas, on the recommendation of a co-worker, and was not dissapointed with my experience and take-aways!

Immediately upon entering, I was greeted by a few shopkeepers from the back of the sleek space. Shelves of big canisters to the left, low wooden tables with Chinese tea service setups and shelves of pots, mugs, and other merch to the right. A young, very knowledgeable and upbeat Chinese girl approached me right away and made suggestions based on my statement that I need something strong that will be good for drinking all day. She sat me down to try a couple different teas,  and showed me differences in the tea based on steeping temps, 2nd and 3rd use of leaves, suggested I eat fresh tea leaves in my food (which I purchased -just cut a couple of months ago), and gave me some to try.  

I did leave with $60 worth of green and oolong varieties, as well as a porcelain mug with a lid and porcelain straining insert that she said would be great for refilling all day at my desk (and it is!).
 
I am a big tea lover; don't do coffee, and am really enjoying discovering places like this in SF. I am curious to visit others, and may have hoped for a more vast selection (although theirs wasn't skimpy),  but I'll definitely be back, particularly since I was treated with so much hospitality and left with new ideas about enhancing something that's such a constant part of my daily life.  Thank you Red Blossom! You really leave little to be desired.
author: Adrienne K.

description: Really love this place.  Wonderful, knowledgeable staff, great teas and beautiful tea sets for sale.  We were so fortunate to sit down with Alice and have her demonstrate and explain her tea techniques.  She is such a kind, funny and knowledgeable proprietor.  We loved being in the shop, and will return on future SF visits.
author: David V.

description: I think this is one of the best tea shops in San Francisco! It's definitely one of my favorites. The staff is very friendly and knowledgeable! And their tea selection is top quality! I bought some wild fresh (sheng) pu-erhs there that are out of this world! Highly recommended!
author: Tim A.

description: They have very high quality tea and are willing to let you taste the higher priced teas before you buy them. Lovely oolong and green tea selections, as well as flavored and floral teas, such as che sen, lotus tea, and jasmine teas.
author: Vena V.

description:
We stumbled upon this little gem during the Chinese New Year Festival. I am a huge fan of herbal tea since I do not drink caffiene. 

Red Blossom has a non-caffienated Chai (just the spices), which is unheard of! I have not tried it yet because I have two other favorites that I keep buying! 

My favorite is the lavender tea. 100% lavender. It tastes like it smells, but it's not bitter at all. It's wonderful! It's relaxing and more flavorful than chamomile! My other favorite is the mint with roses! Their mint tea is top notch and so fragrant. Sometimes I just want to open the bag and smell it.... Other herbal teas include rose, jasmine, and chamomile (all pure flowers with no other teas added).

This is a hip little modern tea house nestled in with the older, traditional Grant Ave tourist shops. Such a refreshing shop. I have not sat down for a tea service yet, but I plan to on my next stop. 

This would be a great place to do some Christmas/gift shopping. They will vaacum seal and bag your tea for you as you select it and they encourage you to smell the tins. You get a lot of tea for your money since they charge by weight. 

The staff are polite and knowledgable on brewing techniques and any other tips you may need. 

They sell an array of tea accessories like tea pots and cups and also have a large selection of ginseng.
author: Susanna B.

description:
I'm not a tea expert, but Red Blossom Tea Company makes me feel like I know a little more than the average consumer.

As a culinary student in San Francisco, my chef instructor took me to this place for a tea tasting. They really know their stuff. They broke it down for us on how you should properly brew tea and which tea would probably suit your taste the most based on your preferences.

If you want to learn more about tea or get help finding a tea that will suit your taste, I really recommend checking this place out and talking to the staff. You may look at tea in a new light and find depth to this beverage.
author: Lih-Wern W.

description: Every kinda tea you could ask for! They are super knowledgeable and are willing to let you taste. I had fun. It was a great escape to the busy streets of Chinatown.
author: Ladybird G.

description:
Having tried over a dozen providers of loose leaf tea in the US, Red Blossom Tea is hands down the best.  These people know their stuff.  They will take time to talk to you about them much like it's a bottle of wine.  

Their product itself is amazing.  It is some of the best loose leaf tea I've had.  The Dragonwell tea is the best I've had and people might be surprised what real Dragonwell tastes like.  Their oolongs are the best and their variety is incredible.

Yes, their prices are high, but to be honest it's worth it.  Not only that, Teavana charges the same prices and their tea is lucky to be half the quality of Red Blossom.  They are a small business and they know their stuff.
author: Drew T.

description: We had a great experience with Red Blossom staff.  We were given a sampling of hot tea and proper way to get the most out of each brew. They spent time having us smell the bins and describing the flavors.  We purchased 4 teas/chais and enjoyed the experience.  The tea we tasted was great and we expect the same from our purchases.
author: Kim D.

description:
Sit for a spell, these folks will definitely stir you the right direction.

Take your time hear, this place is a jewel.
author: Debbie S.

description:
Tourist trap.  He didn't even know what teas are for what ailment.  Give me a break.  He down played the value of tea in the medical value.  The gentleman that help me is photo here.  If you were trying to get medical teas or anything like taste.  This is not the place.  This is extremely well kept tourist trapped.  I'm not saying that the teas are bad quality.  I am saying if you are going to looking for teas for enjoyments and or health benefits don't come here looking for help or advice.  He's extremely rude and brushed you off as soon as you ask intelligence questions. 

If you are  someone who  wasn't trying to get help on which teas that have  any value and not street- wise junk that a tourist wouldn't know from adam this is the estiblishment.  DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME HERE.

I guess HINA'S TEA IN SACRAMENTO has given me the utmost tea experience.  She knows her teas.
author: China Doll B.

description:
