The Red Blossom Tea Company was stop #2 on my "Eat my way through SF" weekend tour. After a tea for two at Leland's we made our way to Chinatown to this store my cousin and friend had visited and been introduced to during a walking tour of Chinatown. 

I love the story behind this. A son and daughter took over the store their parents ran and modernized it. The place looks VERY different than its counterparts down the street. Mom and dad are still there, and on this day that we went in so was the daughter but the son was overseas tending to business. (They're very hands on with the whole tea leaf process)

The family is very willing to answer questions and let you taste any of the teas. After sniffing half the barrels in the store I bought 5 Green tea Jasmine blossoms which I can put in a glass, pour hot water over and watch the flower blossom like in Marie Antoinette!
author: Lori K.

description:
The Dwight Schrute's of  tea!
Are you a pretentious tea snob?  If the answer's yes, then you will make plenty of friends in this shop. I subtracted a star for smugness.

In their defense, they know what they are talking about but did they have to laugh at every question I asked?  I enjoy a good amount of tea but apparently, I know jack. 

The tea we bought is incredible and I'm glad I stepped into this shop, but I will say that ol' ego of mine is deeply hurt by them.
author: Natalie W.

description:
A friend of mine was raving about this place, so when it came time to buy holiday gifts for some colleagues and business acquaintances, I went to check it out.  

I trusted my friends' judgment regarding the quality of their tea, but I didn't realize how right-on he was until I actually visited the store. It is immediately apparent when you enter that this is not an apothecary  with herbs, but a tea shop that sells tea for enjoyment. If you're looking for steak, you wouldn't slam a vegetarian restaurant for not having it now, would you (Ok, maybe some of you nutcases would)?  

He introduced me to their Dragon Pearl Jasmine, which I got a ton (ok, not really a TON, but a lot) of--and they have 3 grades if you want to go totally high end, mid-range or low-end. There is a difference in quality and flavor--just ask them. 

Since then, I have tried their caffeine-free chai, their jade chai, the thai, and the vanilla orchid (a black tea). I am not a proper tea brewer (sorry Alice for violating your family's lovely tea!) and I often leave the tea steeping too long. Fortunately for me their tea is such good quality it is very forgiving and I have never had a bitter brew yet from the tea I have purchased here--which is less than I can say for other tea I've had. 

Be sure to check out their tea paraphernalia too, and if you have time, stick around for a tea tasting. You'll learn a lot. ;) They're also really friendly and warm. One of my new favorites.

Oh, and wanna know a secret? For a few bucks, they sell these little filter bags so you can travel with your tea and never drink bad tea again. I carry a few with me, along with a couple of different kinds of tea. Now all they need to start selling are little tea travel kits. Seriously...
author: N B.

description: There are lots of tea shops in San Fran's Chinatown, but this little shop caught my eye. It was pretty inviting, and like many of the others very small. Instead of a long tea bar this shop had several canisters of tea on the walls and you could opt to taste the different teas after you selected. The staff was very knowledgeable and I was able to watch the brewing of the tea and sample it before taking it home. I was also given directions on how to brew the tea in my set of teaware, so I didn't feel like I had to buy every tea product in the store. The even packed my tea in an airtight baggie, so it was super easy to put in my carry-on. I was all about this place.
author: Channa P.

description:
I wish we had this place in Columbus! Stopped in during a vacation to San Fran and was completely impressed.
The entire staff was very knowlegable and friendly. They helped me pick out some great gifts for my sister and educated me on the art of tea.
author: Iris C.

description:
No more tea bagging for me! I succumbed to the loose leaf craze today when I set foot into Red Blossom. Big canisters of tea leaves line the store from floor to ceiling, and tempting aromas escape when you open the lid -- from chai to caramel to nectar to mushroom. I was like nasal tripping.

The selection and scents were overwhelming until Jennifer grabbed a hold of us and gave us the 101. She sat us down at the cute little tasting table to try a Tung Ting Oolong, and it tastes like spring and smells like the gardenias in my grandmother's backyard.

The teas start at about $7 per quarter pound, which is about 32 servings, and each can be re-steeped 3 or 4 times for ever bolder flavor with each cup. Yes, as you can tell, I'm a convert. So don't tea-se me with your Mighty Leaf... I want the real thing!
author: Nicole G.

description: Best tea house, ever. I have always received perfect customer service. The teas that are sold here are of the highest caliber. I have patronized red blossom for many years and will continue to do so for many more.
author: michael s.

description: One of the best places in Chinatown for tea and ginger.  The selection of teas is top notch and the sales people are friendly and knowledgable.
author: SF F.

description:
I am sitting here looking at about $50 in tea from this place as I write this.  The Green Chai maybe the best Chai tea I have had ever. period.

Wonderful combinations of herbs and spices with teas.  Very helpful staff.  Increible tea tastings and lots of education.

and the dried and salted fruits are really good too.  

little spendy tho - (minus 1 star)
author: Samanta V.

description: This place is awesome for a true tea lover and a great place to learn about tea for the novice. They make you tea (gorgeously) and tell you everything, letting you smell and sample to hearts content. A lovely excursion.
author: Kerthy F.

description:
When i'm not in SF i order my pu-erh from Red Blossom by mail. They have the best teas in the country.

The service is amazing, these people know their teas. It is not a tea salon created for atmosphere, it is a shop created to get you the best tea. Sometimes the shop is full and busy and you will not get all the attention you wish. But go to buy a yixing pot and they will sit you down and serve you different varieties of the kind of tea you plan to use the pot for - last time we sat there for over an hour tasting teas and comparing, other customers would sit down with us for a while to get a sip.

This is the second generation of tea professionals now running the shop, very knowledgeable in storing and aging the teas. Some of their SF-aged pu-erhs are now being asked to be bought back to China because of how well they have developed.
author: nor n.

description:
I found this place in my search for Thai Iced Tea. Luckily I found this place and was able to buy it because it can be pretty expensive at a restaurant or at one of those boba drink places.  You can even buy their tea online. The other thing that is difficult in making thai iced tea is finding a recipe online that taste like the thai restaurants do. Someone who works at Red Blossom makes it often and knows exactly how the thai restaurants make it. She told me the secret is to allowing it to brew for hours. She told me that she even let it sit overnight. 

The woman at Red Blossom likes her tea a little stronger than I like mine. After experimenting a few times I found out that the only way to get it to taste like the restaurant is to let it steep for several HOURS or allow it to simmer for several hours.

Here is what I do:

1. 1 or 2 tbsp per cup of water

2. Get water to a boil, turn stove off, add tea leaves, let steep for a couple of hours or so, bring back to boil, allow steeping again.

3. Strain in pitcher

3. I use splenda instead of sugar and that does not compromise the taste for me at all

4. Pour half and half, evaporated milk, or condensed milk to taste. (I think condensed milk is the traditional way, but I use what I have on hand plus it has a stronger taste than half and half which is what I use)


Red Blossom has many different kinds of tea and the people there are so helpful. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone who enjoys loose leaf tea.
author: Kimberly H.

description: I used to come to this place from time to time.  The service is hit or miss, they have that  "I am a tea expert, and you don't know shit" attitude.  But the quality of the tea was consistent, so I still went back whenever I run out of tea.  During my last visit though, the service had gotten a lot worse.  I asked them about the increase in price, and they acted like if I can't afford it, then I shouldn't be here.  It's extremely unfriendly.  I understand that price is affected by the rise in Chinese currency, I'm not stupid, but the way that lady talked was humiliating.  I'll never come back, there are many many good tea companies in the city.
author: Tim R.

description: Red Blossom Tea is a shop of rare serendipity where if what you want is the world's best, you can simply go, enter and discover it.  High craft and selectivity meet farm products - like wine and chocolate, many steps must be done well to best meet nature's favor, create and bring us delicious products.  You need not be an expert to enjoy, and it helps just to be open to enlargement.  Alice and her crew are highly knowledgeable, service is professional and excellent fun can be had.
author: Walter H.

description:
On a trip a couple summers ago, my friend and I wandered China Town and came across quite a few little shops that had tea or were considered tea bars, so to speak.  But as soon as we saw this store we just had to go in and see what they had to offer.   

I have become more intrigued by teas in recent years, being solely a coffee drinker thus far, and found the people running this shop to be extremely helpful, friendly and knowledgeable.    They gave us a whole lesson on how to steep the fresh tea and allowed us to try any type we liked while there.  There was never a feeling of rushing us to make a purchase and onto the next customer.  They were sure to take their time and answer any questions we had.  

We both left as satisfied customers and embarking on a new era of becoming tea connoisseurs.   I will continue to order their tea online and stop in my next time to SF.
author: Brooke C.

description:
As a foodie and a tea connoisseur, I have been enamored with the chrysanthemum (gok bo) teas that are served at Dim Sum and Chinese restaurants.  

Rather than eating dim sum or Chinese food daily, I prefer to be able enjoy the tea in the comfort of my own palace.  Thus, I set out to find some gok bo cha.  I go to every tea place that comes to mind including every Chinese grocery stores such as Ranch 99.  

On a random trek up to SF, I ran across RBTC.  I walk in with intensity in my eyes and my blood determined to find the euphoric tea.  With a huge sigh of relief, I come across 2 types of Chrysanthemum tea at the back of the store.  I bought a quarter pound of each to ensure I got the right one.  

Will definitely be back for some refills...
author: Kevin C.

description:
I came here a number of times last year with my then bf.  We were always seated at a table and tasted at least three of their teas before we would buy several and be on our way.  Always a pleasant experience.

But all that changed one day, and with it my opinion of Red Blossom.

My mom was visiting from out-of-state.  I wanted her to have the same delightful experience I had coming into this tea shop.  My brother loves tea and she was hoping to buy him some for his birthday.

We go in and the store is empty of customers.  So, I politely ask if we can try two different kinds of teas, since they obviously aren't busy.  The woman who usually served my bf and I was curt and would not let my mom and I taste any of the teas.  I've come to the conclusion that you have to prove you have money by regularly going in and spending a fortune, as my then bf did, or you don't get that same privilege.

I was sad and disappointed that my mom didn't get to have the tea tasting experience.  But then we went to Far Leaves Tea in Berkeley, and that made up for it.
author: Kate H.

description: One of my first trips to Chinatown found me at Red Blossom as I wandered around looking for places to taste some tea, and while Red Blossom tea doesn't have quite the tea tasting setup that Vital Tealeaf does, the selection of teas and helpfulness of the staff is impressive enough to warrant the rating that I'm giving. I purchased my first loose leaf tea here and have returned on numerous occasions since then. It's a must stop shop for any trip to Chinatown!
author: Zachary H.

description:
The staff is friendly and knowledgeable. Don't be intimidated, just stop by for a sample. I would be surprised if you don't walk out with some tea. We bought a lovely teacup, got home, and found it was chipped. The owner had a new one waiting for us on our next visit.
I can't wait to try more tea.
author: Mona W.

description: For me this place is kinda socially awkward.. you have all of these touristy run down stores selling trinkets and dried stuff you can't pronounce.... and then you have this store that looks like it could be in Los Gatos or some upscale area... we looked around and bf's mom decided on getting some dried hibiscus leaves... holla...
author: Vicky T.

description: You need to know that Feliz this amazing Tea master knows her stuff in and out. I have never listened to anyone more passionate about tea than i am. Feliz is simply delightful and you will find yourself loving tea as much as she does. Our Tea sample session lasted almost 2 hours and i have to say it was worth every second. You really need to stop here and try some tea even if you are not a tea person, you will love it.
author: A R.

description:
Let me start by saying I love tea.  I love the fragrance of the loose tea leaves, the subtle flavor differences between the varying styles, all of the little accoutrements to make a cup of tea.  I went in after a nice lunch across the street at Empress of China, with my mom, her friends, and my son, all of us tea drinkers, and Alice showed us the varying styles of dragon pearl Jasmine tea, which we just loved, and told us all about how it's picked, when, where, etc.  We found it very interesting.
I don't think this place is pretentious whatsoever so the few reviews that say it is, I have to assume that maybe the writers are somewhat insecure.  Whatever.  The fact remains that their tea is excellent, and they have a beautiful store for you to sip and try the different varieties.  Just go-you won't be disappointed!
author: Holly L.

description:
I would never have discovered this place because trudging through crowded Grant St is never my forte, if not for specific requests from an overseas family member for a $285/tael Wisconsin premium ginseng.  As a side note, the first of those requests was a few years ago so I am over the "these ugly things cost HOW MUCH?!?!?!?!" stage.  

But after so many visits, only recently I realized that those massive canisters stacked against the wall up to the ceiling contain premium loose-leaf tea (I have tunnel vision) and only then I got the idea to try some of them out (I love free stuff) whilst the staff were painstakingly putting those overpriced little things in their packaging.

Their teas are no joke - some came with eye-popping price tags.  I settled for a quarter of a pound of the (white) dragon jasmine tea and a tea infuser, and after signing the credit card slip, I couldn't help thinking that, as much as I hate to admit, these guys do make Teavana look like a fast food chain.
author: Ange L.

description:
These guys deserve 5 stars. They deserve every one of them. Their service and knowledge of the product are unparalleled (there's even an herbal pharmacy in the back),  and the overall quality of their product cannot be beat (seriously).

However the store can be a bit cramped and not every tea is available to try before you purchase. But that said, if you want quality service and quality product, Red Blossom simply cannot be beat.

Oh! Also, the staff is extremely helpful and polite. Really. Super nice folks.
author: Michael K.

description:
Lon ago, when they were named under a different name, and the daughter had to just put everything into inventory, I wandered in, new to tea, willing to try, looking hopeless and uncomfortable due to the wet socks and soggy coat.  Alice ( I believe that's her name) gave me a bucket for my umbrella, a napkin to wipe the rain from my face and some green tea with ginseng, just so I can ward off the cold.  She showed me white tea peony, rose scented black, lychee, thai tea (unsweetened), jasmine scented pearl dragon tea, yin hao green, sencha in the powder form good enough for traditional tea ceremony, and as she rolled the names off the tip of her tongue, I was silently crying for I was warm and listening to poetry.

Really, you can't find anyone more friendly and passionate about tea.
author: Tangerine L.

description: I have to add my voice to the chorus of praise for Red Blossom.  I wandered in because I could see that they had the good sense to store the bulk tea in light-proof stainless steel containers instead of tea-killing glass jars, and found them friendly, helpful and very knowledgeable without being condescending.  I bought some Gu Yu-class West Lake Longjing,  better tasting and less pricey than a similar grade from Teance, and saved myself a trip across the Bay.
author: GarySoup I.

description:
I'm a recent arrival, and i must say that my love for this city was consummated with the discovery of this tea shop that sells ounces of loose leafs with prices approaching those of crack.
I was bumbling about at the Autumn Moon Festival this weekend and ducked in from the crowded street to be pleasantly greeted by a wall covered with selves stocked with canisters full of the leafy goodness; veritable tea porn to an aspiring aficionado like myself. Even though the store was quite bustling because of the Festival, the staff was very attentive and considerate. I only picked up some jasmine this time because of familiarity, but i'm looking forward to going when it's a little quieter and asking the staff to turn me on to something new.
author: annie d.

description: The lady with a smile like Mandi Moore is so helpful!
author: Caroline B.

description:
I love this place! 

The interior is clean and organized with labeled barrels of tea leaves.  I think this is why I was drawn here initially....OHHH CLEAN!  

Don't be intimidated if you don't know anything about tea.  The owner saw that I was trying to decide what to get, and came up and helped me out.  He's very honest and knowledgeable (he REALLY knows his tea), and doesn't push the high priced teas (unlike the Dragonlady at Ten Ren..ugh review to come later).   

I ended up with a bag of very reasonably priced middle grade green tea.  I'm used to drinking green tea that my family brings from Beijing's finest tea shop, and couldn't really taste a difference.  Time to tell my parents that they failed at raising a refined Chinese daughter.
author: Tinny S.

description:
I very much liked the place, although my girlfriend thought the lady came across as snobby  - but I thought she was more informative and educational.  If you buy a premium tea, you get a free tasting.  The tea selection is great and the quality of their teas is very high. 

It was easy to tell that not only is the staff very knowledgeable about tea, but they are also passionate about their tea and share that with their customers.  

Highly recommend.
author: Randall S.

description:
I visited this shop while in San Francisco as it came highly recommended by other tea dorks that I know. Truth be told, it seemed as though Red Blossom had some fine teas, but I was a little underwhelmed.
It was crowded with people, which I guess is a good indicator that this place is well received. However, I didn't really appreciate the general attitude of the staff. While admiring teas, I was approached by an employee who looked like she had intentionally dressed as Indiana Jones that morning (I assumed it was a uniform of sorts). She answered a question of mine rather condescendingly, but continued to follow my friend and I around, as if we weren't trusted to touch anything. I went towards the back of the shop, where I saw herbs, and we were basically ignored by the gentleman there. I felt in general, from the interaction I did have with the people here, treated as if I didn't know the first thing about tea. 
I had planned to take a few lovelies home, but left empty handed with absolutely no desire to go back.
author: Sarah Louise F.

description:
The place was full of middle-aged yups on their cell phones. We were hoping to see a wide variety of greens, and perhaps take part in a tasting. You can handle the tins (I saw more than one drippy nose smelling the insides of the lids), but you can't drink the tea!

A small bar in the back for tastings would be phenomenal. 

The place is very minimalist in decor, which is fine. A woman (perhaps an owner) was gracious in asking us if we had questions, and offerering a small cup of a ready brewed green with rose infusion (actually not bad).

So to come here, you should know what you want, or judge it by your nose. And be prepared to unwillingly learn cell phone snippets about the lives tourists and natives alike. The tiny space holds your ears captive.
author: Karen B.

description:
We have been to this tea shop many times while  in the city on business. If there is a tourist crowd inside we walk around until they're gone.  I think they are on the China Town walking tour route.  It's small so you won't get the attention you need if a lot of people are around.

That said, we love this place.  The brother and sister who own and run Red Blossom are always informative and attentive with us.  We usually go with a different "tea focus" at each visit.  Sometimes Oolong,  other times black, green or white. So many different taste profiles! The owners usually have good suggestions.  Typically they'll brew a sample of our choices to help us make our decisions.  Many times along with our purchase they will give us a sample of something new to try at home.

Also, they have these great inexpensive red metel tea containers in various sizes.  I highly recommend these if you are purchasing teas to help keep them fresh.  Oh and I agree with previous reviewer, in that the owners do not steer you to the higher priced teas, they seem to be able to gauge your pricing/tastes needs after talking with you awhile.

Really a great experience if you're in China town whether your new to loose leaf tea drinking or are diehard expert.  We always have good time here and learn/taste something new everytime. 

The only sad thing is that we are not traveling to the City as often as we used to, but the upside is that they have website which we plan to order our tea from in the future.
author: cathy C.

description: Super friendly staff. They were serving 40 yr old Oolong for taste testing to another couple and just offered us the 2nd and 3rd infusion while we were browsing and waiting on the sale staff to package up our bought tea. Very good quality tea. And they know their stuff. Highly recommended and **WILL** return for more
author: Rrr X.

description:
Wow..this store is the most boring tea store I've been to. Yes, sometimes tea stores need charisma and charm to make it stand out from the crowd. So you know what is missing here? Yes, you said it..UNCLE GEE!!

Go to Vital Tea Leaf for the real exciting tea experience. Only go here if you think you are an arrogant tea snob who is only interested in actual years, harvest dates, and different grades. Boring. blah blah blah. 

Yes, Red Blossom Sucks. Peter sucks too. And his sister..wow..don't get me snoring here. zzzz

And, oh yes, one more thing...where is your BLUE TEA?? Get some blue tea god damn it!
author: Run Sing M.

description:
About a year ago, I became obsessed with tea. I went through the yellow pages and the internet, made a list of every tea cafe and tea shop in San Francisco, and tried every one of them. 

Red Blossom was the best. I buy 90% of my tea from them. (I also get a couple from Imperial Tea Court, my 2nd fav place.)

Why I like it above all the others:
- Very high quality teas, stored properly  
- Good selection of types of tea at various price points
- Excellent value for the money, both for the teas and the yixing teapots 
- Friendly, knowledgeable owners, who will take the time to tell you about the teas, show you how to brew them, and give you tastes of the ones you're interested in. No attitude, just people who are passionate about tea.

The shop is very pleasant, clean and light with a soothing decor, and the teas are all in stainless steel cannisters. Each cannister has a label with a detailed description of where the tea came from,  when it was harvested, and what its aroma and taste are like. The shop is narrow and so can get a little crowded when they're busy.

I have spent many happy hours here  - sniffing the teas, tasting the teas, and learning about them from Alice. I love this shop.  Every morning when I make my favorite, the alishan spring oolong, I am so glad I found Red Blossom.
author: Debi L.

description:
amazing teas!!! some of the best ive EVER had!!

super knowledgeable, friendly staff

store is a trip.. clean and serene.. right in the middle of chinatown

expensive but WELL WORTH IT!!!!
author: jo jo j.

description:
What a gorgeous store. I popped in here one weekday afternoon looking for some loose Genmaicha. The staff was so kind and knowledgeable! 
And it is as delicious as the tea I have with at my local sushi joint.
I'm definitely making Red Blossom my only tea stop spot.
author: Nicole L.

description:
A while back I took a Chinatown tour.  Some very good times...  Probably my favorite stop was the Red Blossom Tea Company.  When they said, "visiting tea shop" this was not what I was expecting.  The store was beautiful, their selection was fantastic, and the service was great.

We had a tasting of tea during our tour; the owners daughter talked at length about the different varieties and origins of tea...

I returned after the tour to buy some tea.  I couldn't imagine myself spending hundreds or even thousands of dollars on tea...who knows, if I had the ability I may have...but I bought an entire pound of green tea for $12.  I then went on to pass out little bags of said tea to friends and family.  They even give you a free tea strainer with your purchase.

Oh, and if you want an interesing story about tea-mistaken-for-weed, contact Lori K.
author: Melanie V.

description:
*Special Note: Don't let the tourists fool you -- ignore them -- go in as a local, talk to Alice -- this place may be on the tourists' map, but it is not _for_tourists_*

I drank tea before I came to this place, but now I am a tea drinker. Subtle, but important distinction. Bagged green, English breakfast, or random *cha at the local sushi joint was all I knew. Pearl Jasmine was the height of tea-cool-ery for me. Clearly, I was lost in the desert outside the walls of the lush Tea City. 

Red Blossom lead me into the abundant bazaar of the that city's streets. Alice's introduction to Oolongs and Puh-Erhs changed my morning-beverage world the way my first sip of a Belgian Triple changed my evening's. Let her lead you, folks -- just saunter right up and say "Alice, please recommend some amazing tea." She'll steer you right, and won't overcharge an undeveloped palate -- many times she has recommended a lower grade tea, sensing that I might not be ready to appreciate some of the extra $4/oz flavors of the highest grade stuff.

Though they carry the full range of teas, they specialize in Chinese teas and show a clear disdain for Japanese greens and English blacks -- I can't help but agree with them at the moment, though maybe I need to be schooled by a less biased source. However, trust Alice and you will taste teas you couldn't have imagined were possible.

Their prices are as fine as their teas and a perfect value for the introductory to the hard-core tea lover.

I repeat myself: the greatest thing about this place after the remarkable taste of the teas they vend is the personal attention of the incredibly knowledgeable and friendly Alice -- Share some tea with her!

And again about tourists: This is one of those strange places where local excellence and touristical big-footing cross paths. Of the many times I've been to Red Blossom, only once has my stay been marred by an ignorant cart-load of Patagonia-wearing camera-toters --it wasn't that bad, and besides, I like to see the Blossom get all the business it can.
author: John F.

description:
Wow... I used to have such high regards for Red Blossom Tea Company but after my last trip, I'm sorry. I don't think I will ever go back.

Red Blossom has a lot of good quality teas and cheaper prices than most of the Chinatown area. They take care of their stock well and have a lovely interior. For this, I did regard them as a good tea store.

However, their level of customer service is incredibly subpar, especially when it comes to tea tasting. I understand not wanting to allow everyone to taste your stock, especially when you will get people who only want to taste and not buy, but I walked in with the explicit statement of "I want to buy a white tea, but am not sure which one" and was wanting to taste samples from that family so I could purchase one that I liked. Considering they are a store that offers free tea tasting, that seemed like a reasonable request. 

They allowed me to try their Silver Needle b/c another group was already trying it out, but after that, the lady refused to help me b/c "trying teas from the same family doesn't allow you to taste them". Funny, b/c they had no problems doing that last time when I was purchasing a green tea. (Last time also, they told me I could only try 3 and the time before, they told me I couldn't try a white tea after trying an oolong b/c the taste of the oolong would drown out the white (at least the last statement made logical sense b/c the oolong's taste was strong). I do wonder if they're just pulling excuses out randomly...).

I told her I wasn't about to purchase the Silver Needle w/o trying the others first, especially when the Silver Needle was priced at $165/lb while the others were around $50/lb. That's when she made that excuse.

So in the end, I left without buying anything and went down the street to Vital Leaf (which, by the way, I had to tell them to stop offering tea tastings b/c they were being so generous with them). Vital Leaf is way more expensive than Red Blossom, but for their services and welcoming attitudes, I was happy to purchase some teas from them. 

Honestly, without the hospitality, why should I buy any tea in an expensive tea store? If you don't let me try, what's the difference from me closing my eyes purchasing a box from a typical Asian market?
author: Theresa C.

description:
I've lived in SF for 3 years, searched all over the city (looking for a local and non-touristed place), and I found Red Blossom. As some others have said, don't let the tourist neighborhood fool you. This is the best place in SF to buy and learn about loose leaf tea. 

Alice is wonderful (and Peter). If you want high quality tea or you want to start learning, go here. Spend some time smelling the tea and ask questions. Alice gets really excited and will tell you so much so you can learn so much. 

I've been a customer for 3 years. I've learned so much. I love tea and love shopping here more than any where else. 

On a practical note, they have a wide variety from the basic (aka affordable) to the highest quality (expensive). If you want to try tea (to see if you like it), then start with the basic stuff. Then slowly move up. As a rule of thumb, if you like the smell, you'll usually like the taste.
author: Kenneth K.

description:
Why? Because they spent a ridiculous amount of time serving us a beautiful oolong which he readily admitted was his favorite. Because I didn't have to buy anything right away.

Because boutiques that not only whole-heartedly believe in their mechandise but that trust you will be back again are a rarity and worth patronizing... 

Why buy tea somewhere else? Ignorance isn't much of an excuse after you've read the reviews, buddy.
author: Andrew W.

description: BAIT AND SWITCH!!! I selected a mid-to-late 90s Puer, which cost over $40 for a quarter pound bag. They went away and made a bag of it and then came back, always a very bad sign. Sure enough, when I was back in the office I opened the bag and found a tea no more than 2 years old. You can tell right away because of the earthy smell, completely different than in the store. It's like the difference between smelling a wet and a dry blanket. There's no way to verify the tea without opening the sealed bag. They obviously hide when they pour and seal it so they can trick you. I took it back and they said over and over "absolutely no return for any reason". What a scam! Then I took the tea to two other shops and asked them if they could match it, just to make sure I wasn't losing my sense of smell. Both places offered me their youngest Puer. After I told the story to the third place they said Red Blossom has a bad rep and actually offered to exchange it for the real thing. Now I go there instead. IF YOU GO HERE DON'T LET THE TEA OUT OF YOUR SIGHT - DON'T LET THEM SCAM YOU
author: Mulberry S.

description: Came here for a work event and had a nice tasting.  It was very educational and I got some really great tasting teas from it.  Very pleased.
author: Harold B.

description:
Great Atmosphere, Great Customer Service, Very Knowledgeable, Great Teas. 

A fun, clean shop to stop in, browse, and sample the exquisite and  some rare teas. Also, a great selection of high grade chinese herbs.
author: Michael Joseph Fitzpatrick F.

description:
I am not a tea connoisseur by any means.  But I like a good green tea, and can tell the difference between the stuff here and the stuff at the supermarket.

The interior of Red Blossom is really beautiful, and the sales people are extremely friendly and knowledgeable.  They really know their stuff too.  When I went here with my girlfriend, she was able to talk to the proprietors in Mandarin and find exactly what kind of tea she wanted to get me to counterbalance the "fire" foods that I was eating (it turned out to be dried Chrysanthemum blossoms).

If you sit down at the table in the front, you can sample their teas and talk to an expert there about what kinds you like and they'll help guide you to a purchase.  The prices are reasonable too.  Five stars for Red Blossom!
author: Evan K.

description:
Must be the best tea house in SF. Peter is very knowledgeable, patient, and sure to set you up with a brew you will like. You can tell he really cares about tea, and wants you too, also. 

Take a visit and learn something new. Sure, the good stuff can be "expensive", but cheaper than alcohol, and a lot better for you!!!
author: Johnny O.

description:
My friend and I had a great experience here last weekend, when we spent almost an hour and a half talking tea with the young guy there. I think he told us his name, but I'm bad with names. Anyway, we were a pair of obviously non-rich, goofy, overly enthusiastic young ladies but he treated us to tastings of two different teas and we were there past closing, smelling the wares and eventually buying more than we could afford. It was such fun.

I know the owners are yelpers themselves (at least the woman is) and are probably reading this - thanks for your time and consideration, you really made our day. 

That being said, if you're going to go here, don't expect to be served tea (they do tastings, but this isn't a Starbucks) and expect to have your picture taken by random midwesterners. Just because it's in Chinatown doesn't mean it's a museum piece, people. A bunch of tourists came in and just gawked. So, that was kind of unpleasant, I guess, but it's not the company's fault.
author: Simone M.

description:
Red Blossom remains my favorite place to buy tea on the West Coast. The store is attractive, the teas are very fresh and the staff is both knowledgeable and passionate.

My only complaint is that the store is located on the main tourist street in Chinatown. On my first visit, I walked in with my 3 Year old daughter on my arm and was greeted across the room with "We don't serve tea here!" Well . . . Books and covers . . . I started talking tea with them and before you knew it they were serving us tea . . . Lots of tea, tea that was hidden in the back, tea while unfolding maps and enough tea to keep us a just past my wife's point of patience for indulging her husband. While the store could have a slightly larger selection of Pu-erh, I won't fault them as all their tea was top grade and fresh. They also have a great selection of Oolong to boot!
author: M Jason B.

description: Been coming here for years and the service and the quality of teas are second to none.
author: Roger H.

description: We got a set of tea cups and teas as a gift from this place. We got the Dragon Pearl Jasmine which has quickly become an office favorite. Very flavorful and aromatic. They also curry accessorites from diffusers to teapots. Great place to stock up on all sorts of different teas.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Teavana needs to be run out of every town it tries to get it's minions to follow 'cause this place is the bomb! Granted, there are loads of tourists and people who have no business sticking their noses in the tins and manhandling the teas in the back but I grew up with tea and I feel like it's a  place of peace when I walk into any medicinal/herbal shop. 
I wanted to thank Matt for dinner and since my wine knowledge is like that of a pretentious Wrigleyville yuppie (meaning I know my wine, but I can talk and buy a better game than I do appreciating it) I opted for leaves instead. And yes they have rolled leaves that blossom as they seep in hot water and they have the popular blossoming tea pot sensations but what makes me want to come back time and time again is the owner of the shop? I think he's the owner. I gave him a sample of what I was used to drinking but the shop I frequented was from D.C. and there's no way I'm going to find the Jasmine tea I use in my J.W. Gold Label from Safeway. He breathed it in and found me a suitable pairing and explained the subtle notes and intensity. Awesome awesome intensity from this guy! He'll look at the wall for a moment, grab the tin and move it away from himself as you take a breath in. I got dragon ball pearls and jasmine leaves for myself and Matt. I'm so impressed with the knowledge and the time he took to explain about the process even though the store was extremely busy and I'm sure he could have made a killing with every tourist that walked in. 
I still have a few pearls left and the aroma just fills the kitchen. I can't wait to go back and try some new ones. They give you a handy little bookmark to help you differentiate teas and seeping times. The place definitely isn't like the normal Chinatown tea shops you're used to seeing and it's almost chic I'd say but don't let the new decor throw you off-it's old school at heart. Good luck finding parking and finding this place though. I almost hired a sherpa to find this place but again, it's well worth it.
author: Jessica K.

description: As a form of apology, the owner/taster sent some free tea samples with my friend for me to try. It was a nice enough gesture to warrant an additional star. I appreciate the apology. The substance of my previous review stands. I won't be shopping here.
author: S. T.

description:
A fan of loose leaf teas?  Well look no further.  The newly renovated store front is a tea-lovers paradise.  The staff is super friendly and super knowledgeable about all their teas.  They also have demonstrations and tea tastings in case you have problems deciding from their huge selection.

If you need a suggestion, go for the Dragon Pearl Jasmine Supreme.  It's very tasty!
author: Betina C.

description:
Growing up with an English father I am a lover of tea.

Red Blossom Tea Company has tea for people who know how to appreciate tea.

My favorite new tea that RBTC turned me on to is Pu-erh, it is fermented and very earthy with no sharpness.

Also just did a tasting of the Jasmine that comes wrapped like buds, it was so tastey and smooth but too expensive for me.

The more regular types of tea are affordable though, i just got a half pound of Black Rose tea for $14.
author: anders h.

description:
Strolled in here today with my dad who's visiting from Hawai'i...

I casually heard about this place, but forgot that it was on my to-do list.

Well, I fell off of my rocker today!  I received an excellent mini-tea education as well as a fabulous tasting!  The shop owner, well, she was amazingly knowledgeable to boot...:)   

I am passionate about this place and will return many, many more times.

This gets my 2 thumbs up!

Patrick :)
author: Patrick I.

description:
I like how Red Blossom has been able to transform from their old incarnation of a traditional Chinese herbal store to this sort of new, clean, and much hipper tea store. There's nothing new about the variety of Chinese teas here, but the packaging and clean-up at the store really do make a difference.

I bought some of the blossoming jasmine tea buds during my first visit here, and my BF got some "Eight Treasures" tea, which brews up a tasty, probably-good-for-you pot of slightly sweet tea. The prices are pretty decent as well.
author: Andrey C.

description:
I'll agree with Brandon about the quality, but it's not true--you can get tea for $3/oz to $15+/oz. If you're a serious tea drinker, and you don't like fruity herbal blends, then this place is great for you. it's a family-owned business and the younger generation has now taken over. One of the proprietors is a wonderfully geeky, well dressed young Chinese man who knows his stuff. They don't serve tea here like other places in Chinatown, but they will provide you with a tasting if you're considering buying a significant amount of something at least minimally pricey, or just to narrow down your choices. This is serious business--they know what they're doing here, and they store their tea properly. They spend alot of time with customers.

Highly recommended.
author: Caroline C.

description: I grew up the Bay Area and try and get back as often as I can. I found this place by a complete accident about a decade ago and am I ever glad that I did. I am a big time tea drinker (I order tea from China by the Kilo) and every time I am fortunate enough to make my way to The City Red Blossom is one of my stops. As others have said this place is the real deal and there is something for everyone from less expensive . There's something available for everyone who has a love for tea. Red Blossom has a great reputation in internet tea circles though I've never ordered from them online but if their on line business is anythign like th attention they give their stores those ordering on line should be just fine.
author: Bert A.

description: I think this place deserves five stars for every other tea I've tried there. When I visited the girl I was talking to knew a lot about tea. There was only one other person in the store so I received adequate help. I had spent all day walking around SF buying stuff so I decided to get an inexpensive tea. I got a pouch of Jasmine Sparrow's Beak for about $11. I was really disappointed with this tea. I thought it was a 2/10. However every other tea I've had there was very good.
author: Sarah A.

description: This is a very whitey-friendly tea shop in Chinatown. (I say that as a whitey.) Super clean, well organized, mod decor. The sales clerk wasn't crazy helpful, but I was able to buy my mom a nice gift in under five minutes. I'll let you know how she liked the tea; I ended up getting the Golden Monkey black tea after I told the clerk that my mom usually likes English Breakfast. I don't know a lot about tea, so hopefully that was a good recommendation.
author: Emily A.

description:
My boyfriend got me a wonderful, unique Valentine's Day gift from Red Blossom- several kinds of yummy oolong and green teas. When he wanted to go back, I really couldn't resist, and ended up picking out one of the beautiful infusers to go with my tea as well as some canisters. On the weekends (I think) they give you free samples with your purchase. I recently visited yet again to pick up some more tea- an organic qi zhong oolong (which I discovered I loved when I tried the free sample I had gotten) and and Eastern Beauty. 

The staff is really friendly and helpful, and very respectful and knowledgeable. The shop itself is really nicely done, clean and bright. They have a great selection of teas and accessories as well. It has certainly become my favorite place to buy tea (and take friends and visitors).
author: Barbs J.

description:
Great place to find premium teas and teaware at decent prices.  They have a great shop if you happen to be in Chinatown, but their website is equally effective.

One of the very best tea shops in the Bay Area!
author: Chris A.

description: Ok, im a new tea drinker...its my attempt to try something different and stop drinking coffee. I was lured into it by Uncle Gee's demo..but my yelp reviews lead me to Red Blossom. I am a very happy customer...in fact a bit too happy...i think Im strung out on tea now.  Just came from the shop, got my fix...picked up the Jade Green tea Chai, the Black tea Chai, and a sample of the Amber Oolong Ginseng tea...The customer service is amazing..and they are great at educating you on the basics. I was assisted by pretty much everyone at one point or another...my thanks to the cute little redhead that helped me pursue my new habit.
author: Jack F.

description: Considering that the quality of the Natural Tea Company has seemingly declined in recent years, and that I can now hold my own in pretentious tea-offs, the Red Blossom Tea Company is a great place to buy tea. They usually have a wide assortment that's actually organized in some meaningful fashion, and the staff is cordial, if not actually friendly. They can still be aloof, and somewhat belittling, but for the most part they are easy to talk to. They do offer tastings, but with less enthusiasm then other tea shops. I do like them, but with reservations.
author: Herbert S.

description:
Where i get my genmaicha fix in the city, get gifts for my sister, and occasionally knock over an entire set of fixtures with nary a glance from the proprietor....

Plus this place gives me an excuse to walk through chinatown...

Love it!
author: D S.

description:
I walked by this place while perusing the CNY fair booths.  Nice decor and catered toward visitors.  We manage to buy some chinese herb at this store as well.  

website:  www.redblossomtea.com
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Not much to add, but I wanted to thank the reviewers who took time to post about this place.  I'm sure the folks who babysat my daughter and my dog would have preferred wine as thank you gifts, but since I can't carry that on the plane, they all got tea with strainers.  Even though the store was crowded with Saturday shoppers, Alice managed to help me with selections, have my gifts wrapped up, serve us some samples, and tell us a bit about the shop.

Alice and her brother were both very welcoming, and I saw no sign of the pretentiousness mentioned by a few reviewers.  

I'll be placing some orders online when I run out of my stash!
author: Mary C.

description:
Good source for chinese tea.  Most of their tea come from Taiwan and China.  
If you are a fan of tea or learning about tea, Red Blossom won't disappoint.
author: N. C.

description:
I'm all about service, quality of products, and the appeal/design of a place. Red Blossom Tea Company did not disappoint. Since I live relatively close, I always bring my visiting friends (even my tea loving sister) and they always leave with buckets of things. I truly enjoy the staff for their service and knowledge of products. They offer tea service to help you decide. 

They really know their teas and offer some great teas for a great price. They're tea-crazy, but maybe we all should be.
author: Stephanie L.

description: I HEART Red Blossom!  One of my fav's is their "Rose Black" - which is a black tea scented with rose petals served nice 'n HOT... ahhhh, dreammmmy
author: Nikki B.

description: My friend and I came in and was greeted by the very knowledgable staff. She told us about the best green teas they had and if she wasn't sure about something, she asked her supervisor. We bought the the San Lin Xi Spring 2009 Oolong Tea and Ming Qian Dragonwell - Shifeng Green Tea. The prices were competitive and they explained the difference in price. They did a sampling for us and did a more traditional way of serving teas with gaiwan tea and tea trays. It was a great, fun experience. I loved it and learned a great deal more about teas.
author: Linda S.

description: I was never a big tea person. Coffee was really my poison.  Then I met Alice, she maybe the most knowledgeable person when it comes to tea. She was just amazingly sweet and helpful. I walked out of there with 3 bags of tea and I've been drinking it since. This place is just great inside. You are transported into the world of teas and you kinda don't want to leave. The staff is friendly and really wants to find the best blend for you. They are honest and don't just have you buy anything they ask the right questions. They want to make sure the tea you walk out with is the one for you. Go enjoy, ask question, and buy!
author: Lisa A.

description:
Red Blossom does it right.  Alice and Peter are very friendly and do a great job of letting customers taste different teas, and guiding them through the world of of tea varieties.
They may not have the best teas in the world, but they do the best job in San Francisco.  For quality and price, their Taiwanese Oolongs are topnotch.  
Also, no pretense, no obscuring of information, and no misleading stories. Just good tea and great people.
author: David L.

description:
Being a tea newbie, it was a little intimidating to be faced with so many teas.

The staff were great and talked to us all about the different teas, got us smelling all the lids and after talking, sampling, and smelling, we walked out happy with our fave teas of the day.
author: Tom L.

description: I took my three year old granddaughter to Red Blossum today and we had a great tea tasting with Ada.  The tea was delicious, the service superb, and my granddaughter loved it as did I.  Ada was very knowledgable about their teas and how different teas were made and grown.  It was a fun, special experience and I highly recommend it. It is not touristy even though it is on Grant.
author: Carole W.

description: Are you a tea fanatic? A  small space, clean and modern Asian decor. They have a very polite staff. All of their teas are very yummy and they have a wide variety. They will do tastings with you so you can figure out which one you wish to purchase. Just now that when it is busy it can be a bit cramped so your tasting may not have as great service or places to sit. If you see this place not full, definitely take advantage!
author: Ella V.

description: I am a fairly developed tea snob, and Red Blossom is the best tea shop I have ever found. Their selection is far more focused than an encyclopedic mail-order vendor like Upton Tea (also highly recommended), but the quality, service, and atmosphere are fantastic, and the prices very respectable.
author: Jonathan R.

description: We love this place! Sure there are others out there, but for whatever reason this place seems the most upscale and detail oriented Tea purveyor. We always set aside time to sit and taste a few of the tea's and always walk away happy with our purchases. Great selection, better service. If you want to try out some tea and get top notch everything, go here.
author: Sean F.

description: Friendly service and very knowledgeable staff.  Red Blossom has good selection of teas, including traditional, herbal, and special blended variations. They also have other Chinese herbal ingredients. While small in size, the store itself is elegant and well organized.  The even provide a nice selection of traditional Chinese tea cups and tea sets.  My only wish would be that the place were larger  (a Chinese tea house if you will) that would offer more sit down space for imbibing teas. But ironically as may sound, Chinatown may not be the ideal location for a Chinese tea house. For Chinatown, this small tea company cannot be beat.
author: Gregory C.

description:
The tea of course is great, but it is the experience at Red Blossom that makes it memorable.

The level of attentiveness, knowledge, professionalism and friendliness of the staff is incredible. I feel like a regular customer or friend of the family even though I only shop here maybe a few times a year. Alice remembers my preference in green teas and points out the new arrivals of the season, makes recommendations, and invites me to sit down for a tasting.

Over the years you can tell their business has been expanding and I am happy for their success. Red Blossom teas are now appearing in notable restaurants, shops and cafés around town (Wexler's, Bi-Rite Market, Ritual Coffee).

Another recent addition is the wonderful tea ware for sale in the shop. These would make great gifts. I have been eyeing a few of the tea sets for myself...
author: Matt B.

description: Love the tea. It might be a little on the pricey side, but it is well worth it. Plus they have a huge selection so they'll have pretty much whatever yo want. Also a great place to get  gifts for your friends and family that like tea.
author: Russ C.

description: Excellent place to learn about tea.  We are rookies to tea, and we sat down and received education on the tea(several options to choose from), how to brew it, temp to brew the tea, etc.  Great education and customer service.  Only thing is, it is a little pricey, other than that, no complaints =)
author: K. N.

description:
Hands down, this is the best tea you can find in the Bay Area! this family run business puts a lot of effort into sourcing some really excellent tea (mostly from china and taiwan with a few japanese greens thrown in there). 
Peter, the tea buyer, is super knowledgable, friendly and full of information about all the teas they sell.

If you're looking for a thoughtful selection of high quality tea, go to red blossom!
author: Lindsay T.

description:
About a year ago, I decided to investigate something better than supermarket teas. Red Blossom came up in a Google search along with 5 or 6 other tea sellers. I tried them all. 

Red Blossom people almost don't seem to care if you buy ... as long as you learn something and find something you enjoy.

The people are helpful, professional and know their large product selection. They helped me find a good ol' black tea of the sort I grew up with but of super, super quality. Then - at my request only - helped me expand my knowledge and taste into white teas, oolongs and pu'er. 

Fine tea, fine product, I'm a customer for good.
author: Paul R.

description: Highly impressed with the abundance of teas, tea sets and raw herbs displayed in a beautifully renovated shop. The walls are lined with some of the most fragrant and delicious teas I've come across. For a true tea experience, find yourself here for a tasting treat!
author: Stephanie J.

description: I am a huge tea fan cannot stand coffee......And I found this place when I was on vaction there with my son back in July.  I was blown away at the store how sheek it is and clean. I have yet to see a store here with such a wide variety of teas in chicago with the whole WOW me away package. At red blossom you can try any tea and they also have daily sample's. Not only was the knowledge from the employee helpful but she also showed me different use's for different tea's   The Osmanthus Mao Jian "Green Tea" " My daily moring drive to work drink" is great hot or as an ice tea in summer And the Vinilla Orchard " black tea"  is simple heaven...... And love the web site so I can always order online for convience.
author: Carmella B.

description: If you are a tea drinker, this is a great place to go - excellent quality, great selection, and a lovely store. But if you aren't a tea drinker, this would also be a great place to start. The folks there are knowledgable and willing to answer questions. I bought tea to give as a gift, and think the labeled vacuum bag and can I bought, with the instruction card they included will make a great presentation. I'll definitely go back.
author: Amy E.

description: Great place! This place really stands out among others in China Town. You can notice that by their interior design, friendly staff (rare thing in CT), variety of teas, and even their website. I really enjoy going there and get most of my tea supply from them (even though price-wise they may not be the best choice, but I'm willing to pay a few extra bucks for their service and attitude).
author: Dmitry I.

description: This is an incredible place to discover what real tea is all about. It is transformative to smell and taste the teas in this store. All you need to do is smell the oolong teas from Formosa to understand what I mean by that. Those particular teas explode with a sweet floral perfume that is unlike anything you could ever experience in a tea bag. It instantly makes you understand why empires rose and fell over tea. The tea sold here isn't just some beverage, these are refined opulent treasures which you really should try for yourself. You will be happy you did.
author: David M.

description: I'm not much of a tea connoisseur, my favorite is a strong black tea with cream and sugar. Guess it's the British in me, taste buds poorly developed? Nah, you can appreciate good tea even when it isn't in a pure state! Every variety of black tea has it's own interesting flavor and whole leaves of tea taste so much better than mass-marketed "loose leaf" tea with microscopic bits of leaf. Red Blossom Tea Co has a great selection of teas, from white to black. Extra points for having a web site too! I love the organic Golden Monkey, and the Yunnan Black is also fabulous. After two visits I have a bunch of samples of green and oolong to try. The staff are incredibly friendly and seem very knowledgeable. There are a ton of tea stores to choose from, but I think I'll keep going back to Red Blossom.
author: Will A.

description:
I was joyful when I encountered this shop at SF China town. Before that day,  I kept on complaining to my friends about the crappy tea you'll find in either Chinese grocery stores or Peet's. I feel offended to see those places selling two-years old huge leaves of Dragonwell and wanted to have my own shop to introduce really nice tea.

Apparently they did what I wanted to do. When the extremly friendly staff emphasized that they have an exclusive selection of Dragonwell newly picked during march to April from different farms located at different attitude of the area, I know they know something about tea. I tried several samples and very pleased to take some really nice Dragonwell-----best green tea and the best tea for me.

I also love their taste about the tea pot and cups and tray. Simply classic Chinese beauty.
author: James P.

description:
I almost bypassed Red Blossom due to the 1 star review I read about it being a tourist trap.  My experience was the complete opposite.  I found Peter to be very knowledgeable about teas and friendly too.  He gave my wife and I great customer service.  He let us taste several teas and occupy a table for a very long time even though the store was very busy.  He admits he doesn't sell teas for their supposed medicinal qualities.  They have an apothecary in the back of the store for that.  And even there, they'll only fill out presciptions.

Anyway, I think you'd not be doing yourself a favor if you like tea and decide to bypass Red Blossom.  This place deserves a must visit status in SF travel books.

I know Peter reads Yelp.  Told you I'd give you a good review.  You guys deserve it!
author: John D.

description: Red blossom has fabulous tea, and so many varieties.  I love this place.  The service is outstanding as well.  They are extremely knowledgeable about the wide variety of teas available here and how to prepare it. It is well worth the trip to Chinatown for their wondrous teas.  You won't regret it and will soon be back for more!
author: Sunshine S.

description: Wonderful tea selection and very knowledgeable and friendly staff. Left with exactly what I wanted even though I didn't know what it was when I walked in. If you or someone you know loves tea, you can't go wrong with this place.
author: Poppy P.

description:
I rarely visit the store itself, but I always order my tea from Red Blossom Tea. (I've only been inside the store twice -- parking in Chinatown is just a pain.)

Alice at Red Blossom is constantly introducing me to new teas or taking me on tour of some fresh and intriguing tea that has recently come in. She always sends a sample of something interesting together with my orders (not uncommon for tea shops), and she even seems to know what I like. 

My current favorite is their Pi lo Chun Early Harvest. Simply delightful. A lovely looking tea with a great nose and wonderful flavor. I find that it only holds up to a couple of brewings but no matter; it's worth every penny.

Their Silver Needle is always very fresh, and I tried a Pouchong from them today that had a great flowery nose (smells like fresia to me but I'm not an expert on flowers). I've tasted a kuding from RBT that I'm sure was quite good (and definitely fresh), but a bit too tannic for me. It was quite intense with a sort of fruity taste.

Their Dragonwells are always excellent; including the low-end ones. Speaking of which, I typically stay in the $40-60/lb range with their teas and I'm quite happy. (Though I've succumbed to a couple that are a good bit more expensive.) 

RBT offers a great selection of very fresh tea with excellent value throughout their range. Alice will always steer you in the right direction and she clearly takes her tea quite seriously.

Now, I am just getting to know the depth of puerhs and I am drinking their Emperor Puerh in the morning. It's better than the puerh I buy by the pound in New York's Chinatown (about $40/lb, so a bit less), but I don't know -- I'm just not floored by it. Then again, I don't know how well I know puerhs and I can only imagine what those $300 cakes taste like. (Though I did get a very nice bit of puerh from Ying Kee Tea in Hong Kong with a very deep and complex flavor.)

I've sampled a couple of RBT's oolongs and they were very good, but I'm not drinking oolong much these days. I haven't tried any of their black teas, though I'm drinking a tasty Keemun from another tea shop as I write this.

Oh man. There are still so many more teas to try. Well, I'll start tomorrow.
author: WILLIAM P.

description: They have the BEST teas!! It will change the way you think about tea and they are incredibly courteous and helpful. I love that they are philanthropic and give back to the community, but did I mention..they have the BEST teas?
author: Nicole D.

description: This stop turned in to a two hour lesson and relaxation. I walked away with some wonderful teas to enjoy and a better understanding of the product. This was a wonderful time and I look forward to coming back, not only did they recommend other places to go, they took so much time to answer our questions about their history, tea farms they get their products from etc. After a day walking around the city it was a sanctuary. I hope others find this place as much of a treat as we did.
author: Nicole P.

description: very well run. I have been here twice. they are very passionate about tea and the right way to get the most out of it. learned alot. temperature and time are key. And for gods sake! dont drink the first batch! its just getting warmed up!
author: Kahau M.

description: If you're going to buy tea in Chinatown, this is the place. Highly informed owners and the prices are designed for locals, not tourists. All the other joints on Grant street are a RIP-OFF!
author: Chili Bill E.

description:
My friend turned me on to this place, and I was skeptical at first. It's in Chinatown, isn't it a tourist trap? That was two years ago, and I've been coming back every 3-4 months to replenish my supplies. If you like Chinese green tea, you simply have to come here. It's the Blue Bottle of tea stores, specializing in interesting and amazing tea. But unlike your $8 dollar 1/2 pound of blue bottle which lasts a week, your $8 1/4 pound of tung ting will last a lot longer. 

They have some crazy rare high end stuff, but they also have a good range of more affordable teas...although it's all gonna be more expensive than that cheap-ass bagged tea you are used to, but totally worth the extra price. i reuse the same leaves several times, which means that it goes a lot further than coffee or bagged tea.

The brother and sister who run this place are great, friendly, and knowledgeable. They know their ish, and have turned me onto some great teas without making me feel like I am being upsold. My only complaint - i always come here on my lunch break, so have to decline their offer to do tea tastings.
I also had to make a rule for myself - I'll only go there when I'm almost out of tea. Otherwise I'll end up with more than I can drink!
author: Patrick T.

description:
what a great find in the middle of chinatown!  this little tea company is wonderful.  they have a huge variety of loose teas.  the best part is open them and smelling them as you make your selections.  they also give free tastings.  the bad part is that recently this tiny store has been extremely crowded.  the prices are not at all cheap, but try any of their low cost teas and they are often wonderful.
great website aswell
author: charlene l.

description: If you are serious about  teas, this is the place to be. Their quality and selection are superb. I'm sure  Sharon Stone and other oversea stars come here for their teas when they are in town would agree.
author: Will T.

description: Red Blossom has been flying under the radar for awhile, but it may change with their recent gorgeous renovation.  Old or new digs though, it's the tea that counts and their high grade teas will make you swoon. My favorites: Supreme Grade Jasmine Pearl, Silk Oolong (fired with milk for a caramel taste undertone, yum!), and just about everything else they have. Go at a non-busy time, act serious, and you might get a tea tasting and lesson from one of the owners.
author: Celeste S.

description:
What's not to love?  This is a stylish update on a classic tea shop.  The space is sleek and well lit but even more importantly, the selection of fine tea is astounding.  The experts behind the counter will guide novices to the perfect selection or prepare a unique blend for those who know what they are looking for.  

Red Blossom is not a sit-down tea house but, if you stop by at the right time, the owner will brew you a cup what he drinks in the traditional Chinese method while chatting about music, travel and of course, tea.   

This place is worth the trip to Chinatown!  Stop by before it gets discovered by the masses.
author: Lael S.

description: I order about a pound of tea from this shop every month. I almost don't want to spill the beans, but this place lacks the pretense of so many other tea shops, and provides top notch product and service.
author: Wolfram A.

description: I was very unimpressed.  I'm not a tea person, so maybe I don't know what the hell I'm talking about, but I thought that what I could get there for the money was weaker than other tea places I've been, like Leland.   I also found them a little pushy on the sales.  I like to RELAX when I'm buying tea, drinking tea, even thinking about tea.  If I want to get wound up I'll stick with coffee.
author: John D.

description: I love tea. It is a very close rival to coffee and each morning I have a mental debate on which will be my morning partner. Tea wins about half the time. If coffee wins, then tea gets me afterwards as I usually brew a cup at work around 11. Unlike coffee tea is my friend during more times than just when i need a caffeine buzz. When I am sick, it's helps me get better, when I am coldie on a rainy day it helps me feel cozy, when I am trying to chill out after a long day it helps me go to relax when I am hot on a summer day it brings some ice and is the perfect treat. Tea is so versatile and interesting it just really goes with everything. All of these things I already knew about tea, but today I learned I know very very little about tea and was not experiencing nearly as well as I could have been. This tea shop is a beautiful family run business that has incredible staff. We sat down for a tea tasting and in just 10 minutes were blown away with the information we picked up. Plus the teas were really excellent. My mom and I both left wanting to learn more. We bought a new cup so we could steep our tea more accurately and individually. Also a sample pack because we wanted to try so many. I am looking forward to getting to know my friend tea on a much deeper level over the next few weeks and hopefully go back to Red Blossom tea company for another session soon to continue my tea education. Very interesting, you should definitely come by for a visit and quick lesson you wont leave disappointed.
author: Audrey V.

description: Being the total tea snob that I am, I have always been extremely happy with the purchases I have made here.  The store is beautifully designed, the staff is extremely helpful, the selection of tea is marvelous, and the prices are very reasonable.  Those not fortunate enough to live in the area can go to their website and order the tea online.
author: Michael I.

description: Their tea is fantastic -- I tasted it at the Food for Thought Gala hosted by APIAHF and was impressed by not only the flavor, but also presentation and professionalism of the staff.
author: Vera D.

description: This is a great tea shop that was recently renovated to reflect a more posh decor.  You can find traditional teas here such as Pu'erh, but also indulge in mainstream teas like Jasmine or red teas.  It seems that there is always someone that speaks fluent English, and the nonfluent speakers are perfectly capable of placing your orders.  There is also tea sampling and tea tasting!  When I first went here with friends, the shop keeper saw that we just bought tea from another store.  They allowed us to compare our tea to their tea!  The tea here was better!  Now I don't go anywhere else!!
author: GingerSnap G.

description: Someone must have put this place in a guidebook!  Despite the crowds, its still a wonderful place to visit.  The low tables with pots of tea brewing, the metal cannisters of tea on the wall, herbs in the back.  And what nice people they are!  They run around getting this and that, but seem so calm and even ask questions as you check out.  I'm working on a 1/4 lb of Dragonwell (Summer) and 1/4 lb Chamomile (ps.  volume-wise, that is a LOT of Chamomile).  I like to fill my canning jars with tea and cut the labels off the bags to tape to the jars.  Great tea, and a great place to buy.  Cheaper AND much better than buying it at Peets.
author: Ananda Z.

description: Great service and nice selection.  For sure the best tea store in the area.
author: Robert M.

description:
I've been a "tea snob" for quite a while, and this place is about the best I've found.  The staff in the store is really knowledgeable and best of all, willing to sit down and let you try several brews to find the right one.  I live in East Bay and often order from their on-line store (shipping just about balances with the bridge toll).  They ALWAYS ship within a day and often throw in a couple of samples that let you try new teas.   

This one is a real winner.
author: Ken S.

description: Pretentious people who work there?  NO WAY!  My friend Peter co-owns the store with his sister.  He just knows his shit.  He takes the time to explain things to you if you want explainin' -- and if you don't, he'll leave you alone.  Peter, you rock.  You are the god of teas.
author: Lesley G.

description: Good selection of tea.  Friendly knowledgeable family run tea shop.  Lovely tasting opportunity.  Some teas are quite expensive, but obviously also very high quality.
author: daniel g.

description: This place is to tea as Philz is to coffee, though its ambience is more upscale.  In the middle of gawdy, tacky Chinatown tourist traps is this very zen little shop with minimalist design and the best tea I've ever had in California.  The Black Rose is my absolute favorite.   Just don't ruin it with sugar or milk.
author: Gregg B.

description: I started to get into tea about a year ago, and fear I may be turning into a fanatic. Over that time, I've been checking out just about every tea experience I can get my hands on. The more tea shops i visit in SF, the more I'm convinced Red Blossom is the only place I want to buy my tea. Their teas are of the highest quality, and they really seem to care about the product they sell. The experience can seem a bit off-putting if you (like I) aren't an expert, but it's well worth putting yourself out there. I've found the folks at Red Blossom to be incredibly helpful, and I've learned a lot from them.
author: Rob C.

description: This is the place that got me hooked on tea.  They carry a large number of delicious loose-leaf teas.  The brother and sister who run the place are always happy to sample teas, and to talk about tea and non-tea subjects.  They can be a bit on the snobby side (they made fun of my friend's tea thermos, calling it a "toy"), but I can tell it's not in a mean-spirited way.  It doesn't quite get the 5 stars I gave to Golden Tea because it's a little more expensive (I know, it's the location), and because their selection of puers isn't quite as extensive.
author: Daniel F.

description:
I brought a small group of sales folks to San Francisco.  Alice was fantastically patient and expertly dealt with my crowd.  They were awed by the selection of tea and the service that came along with it.

I never knew that I was a tea fanatic until I stepped into the threshold of the Red Blossom Tea Company!  My nose was nearly dead from all the tea I was sniffing!!  

The whole experience is one that I would recommend for a unique experience.  (She also recommends some great restaurants!!)
author: Jenn K.

description: Red Blossom is an oasis amidst the flurry of activity which is Chinatown.  I love to come here on a free afternoon to sample some tea and chat with Alice.  She is very knowledgeable and friendly.  I am always happy with my selections and find that the classy/functional packaging makes their teas the perfect addition to any gift.  My favorite is the Silk Oolong Formosa.
author: Erin F.

description:
Red Blossom has some delicious teas at good prices.  The staff is very helpful and informative if you have questions.  The Dragon Well Reserve is the best bang for your buck if you like greens and is a personal favorite.  The Tung Ting Charcoal Roasted oolong is tasty, but strong.  The Silk Oolong has a very unique flavor and is smooth for an oolong.  It's definitely worth a try, as it's a favorite in my household.

As for getting to the place, I highly suggest parking in the Portsmouth Garage at Kearny and Clay, as finding street parking will be nearly impossible and driving in Chinatown will make you frown.
author: Michael P.

description: Loved the entire experience! Peter walked us through the different kinds of tea, which you can see he's absolutely passionate about and he set up a tasting area with different brews. It was amazing to learn so much about tea in such a short time. He brewed some special ones for us to try and we walked away with our own little stash.. I came back home and brewed some for a bunch of friends and they loved it! The tea here even comes with specific brewing instructions SUPER helpful! Will be going back there to stock up again and try some more new teas!! A big shout out to Peter and we'll see you again soon!
author: S R.

description: More Taipei than Chinatown, this sleek tea emporium is the place to to refine your tea palate. Newly remodeled in August after 20 years, deep knowledge meets high concept. Preparation is meticulous even for a simple taste. First, we used our noses to sample a half dozen complex oolongs from various regions in the mountains of Taiwan. From there, Peter very meticulously brewed a couple of them while explaining the efforts to harvest the tea in different seasons, as well as his personal efforts to locate and import the tea. Then we reseampled the tea for a second brew, and a third. Each revealed remarkably different character...from fruity, to bittersweet, to creamy and buttery. The tea isn't cheap, on the order of $9 - $15 an oz. and they are precious with it.  It's heat sealed airtight in mylar bags, like at a fine cigar store. The back of the store is devoted to ginger root. Old school meets new school.
author: Brandon R.

description:
This is the best and only place in San Francisco where I will buy tea. I have been to other tea shops and none can compare to this jewel in China Town. The staff, Peter and Alice, are friendly, knowledgeable and willing to sit you down and tell you everything about  tea. When we first went there we spent almost 2 hours tasting, talking and smelling many teas. We haven't gone, and won't go, to any other tea shop since and that has been over two years. We have taken friends and family there and all have loved it as much as we do, thankfully, since many are from out of town or country, you can also order online. 
They constantly have new teas coming in, so it is always worth it to go  and have a nice conversation and try their fantastic teas. If you are looking for the best tea in SF come here 
Recommendations: Jasmine Pearl Dragon Supreme, Heirloom Lishan, Heaven Mist (Jade Oolong) or the Grand Scarlet Robe Amber Oolong, nothing beats them.
author: Aaron S.

description: Love this place! They sell great loose leaf tea...my favorite is the Thai Tea...last time I was there it was less than a fiver for a quarter pound. Clean, elegant, nice!
author: Darien W.

description: After reading the reviews, I thought for sure I would have a great "experience" here.  I even called the shop and asked if they have tea tasting the person on the line said of course they do.  Well... NOT TRUE!!!!!!!!!!!!  As I walked in, the sales clerk didn't even acknowledge me or even crack a smile.  I then asked her if I can sample her lychee tea and she said that the taste is straightforward and they SELL sample sizes only.   She said she will not brew me any lychee tea because "the whole shop will smell like lychee tea."  No SH*T.  You are at a tea tasting shop!!!!  The place will smell like tea!!!! I then asked her which tea has the least amount of caffeine she said, "All teas have the same amount of caffeine."  NOT TRUE again.  White teas have the least amount of caffeine and the highest antioxidants.  Needless to say, I walked out empty handed and quickly wrote this review.  I went to Vital Tea Leaf down the street instead and had great customer service there.
author: SillySP P.

description: We went there and talked with Peter.  He was extremely informative on the tea and gave us free yummy tea samples on everything we were thinking of buying.  We walked away with a white tea and green tea (delish).  It has a huge variety of teas.
author: Jaclyn M.

description: I love a pleasant shopping experience, as well as great selection and  quality. Peter and his family at Red Blossom have created a lovely and inviting ambiance. They will also prepare most teas for tasting, (as long as you're intent on buying something!). They walk you through the nuances of tea flavors and textures, sharing the proper language for describing the kinds of teas you like! So if you're ready to take step up in your tea savoring experience, this is a great place to start.
author: Larke B.

description: Okay, I am officially frustrated with how much this place charge on their tea I have to share this with everyone.  First of all, this place is SOOOO pretentious!  That Alice is the most snobbish and arrogant lady (and calling her a lady is being nice) at the store.  She constantly pushes for the most expensive tea.  This is the BIGGEST RIP OFF so save it for the tourists. The tourists don't know any better, but you should.   If you want good and reasonably priced tea, go up a block or two to TIN REN TEA STORE.   The margin they make is at least 300% on the actual price they pay for.  PUH-A-LEASE, who on earth would pay that in this kind of economy??!  Overall, the service is less than average, price is way too high and  they pretend to be a upscale store when it was only an old chinese herbal store a couple of years ago.  Really, do they they by repainting it, add a few chairs and do tea tasting that they think they can demand such obnoxious prices?  Come on!   By the way, there are similar tea shops one block before this sucky place and one block after it so please shop around and you will save a lot of money!  You are warned!
author: David S.

description: I'm still quite a newbie to good tea so can't speak intelligently to the quality of their teas but I can share my experience at the store. A friend and I were doing the Wok Wiz tour of Chinatown and one of the stops is Red Blossom. We walked in and were immediately soothed by the atmosphere and the lovely surroundings. They apparently redid the interior recently and it is fabulous! The staff are very passionate about their teas and they are full of knowledge, which they love to share. My friend and I had to go back after the tour. Normally I'd have been really intimidated by the sheer number of teas they have but once the gentleman who worked there started talking to us, I knew I was in good hands. He described the different types of teas and got us sampling them so we could determine which ones suited us best. The Silver Needle white tea was one of our favorites. I just loved how they served the tea too...with the slotted bamboo tea tray set with the white porcelain Gaiwan and the little teacups. Had to buy the Gaiwan to brew the tea I purchased so at home I can slow down and really enjoy both the process of brewing them as well as drinking them. I highly recommend this place and will definitely go back next time I'm in town.
author: Tara B.
